{{Use mdy dates|date=August 2018}} {{Infobox person | name = Angela Bassett | image = Angela Bassett by Gage Skidmoe.jpg | caption = Bassett in 2015 | birth_name = Angela Evelyn Bassett | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1958|8|16}} | birth_place = [[New York City]], [[New York (state)|New York]], U.S. | residence = [[Los Angeles]], [[California]], U.S. | alma_mater = [[Yale University]] ([[Bachelor of Arts|BA]], [[Master of Fine Arts|MFA]]) | occupation = Actress | years_active = 1985–present | spouse = {{marriage|[[Courtney B. Vance]]|1997}} | children = 2 }}
'''Angela Evelyn Bassett''' (born August 16, 1958) is an American actress and activist. She is known for her biographical film roles, most notably her performance as [[Tina Turner]] in the biopic ''[[What's Love Got to Do with It (film)|What's Love Got to Do with It]]'' (1993), for which she was nominated for the [[Academy Award for Best Actress]] and won a corresponding [[Golden Globe Award for Best Actress – Motion Picture Comedy or Musical|Golden Globe Award]]. Bassett has additionally portrayed [[Betty Shabazz]] in both ''[[Malcolm X (1992 film)|Malcolm X]]'' (1992) and ''[[Panther (film)|Panther]]'' (1995), [[Katherine Jackson]] in ''[[The Jacksons: An American Dream]]'' (1992), Voletta Wallace in ''[[Notorious (2009 film)|Notorious]]'' (2009), and [[Coretta Scott King]] in ''[[Betty & Coretta]]'' (2013). Her other roles include [[Amanda Waller]] in ''[[Green Lantern (film)|Green Lantern]]'' (2011), Lynne Jacobs in ''[[Olympus Has Fallen]]'' (2013) and ''[[London Has Fallen]]'' (2016), and [[Ramonda (comics)|Queen Ramonda]] in ''[[Black Panther (film)|Black Panther]]'' (2018).
Bassett began her film career in the mid-1980s, after earning a bachelor of arts degree from [[Yale University]] and a master of fine arts degree from [[Yale School of Drama|drama school]]. In the 1990s, she appeared in films nearly every year. The 2000s saw a succession of films starring Bassett, with her appearing in at least one film every year. Bassett's success has continued into the 2010s. Bassett earned nominations for her roles in films such as ''[[The Score (2001 film)|The Score]]'' (2001), ''[[Akeelah and the Bee]]'' (2006), ''[[Meet the Browns (film)|Meet the Browns]]'' (2008) and ''[[Jumping the Broom (film)|Jumping the Broom]]'' (2011), and won awards for her performances in ''[[How Stella Got Her Groove Back]]'' (1998) and ''[[Music of the Heart]]'' (1999), among others. Bassett's performance as [[Rosa Parks]] in the 2002 film ''[[The Rosa Parks Story]]'' was honored with her first [[Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Lead Actress in a Limited Series or Movie|Primetime Emmy Award]] nomination.
In 2013, Bassett had a recurring role on the [[FX (TV channel)|FX]] horror anthology series ''[[American Horror Story: Coven]]'', earning her second [[Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Supporting Actress in a Miniseries or a Movie|Primetime Emmy Award]] nomination for her performance as [[Haitian Vodou|Voodoo]] queen [[Marie Laveau (American Horror Story)|Marie Laveau]]. She returned for ''[[American Horror Story: Freak Show|Freak Show]]'', the series' fourth season, portraying a three-breasted woman named Desiree Dupree, for which she received another Emmy Award nomination. For the fifth season, ''[[American Horror Story Hotel|Hotel]]'', she portrayed Ramona Royale, a famous movie star. Bassett returned to the series's sixth cycle, ''[[American Horror Story: Roanoke|Roanoke]]'', portraying an alcoholic actress named Monet Tumusiime, who plays struggling mother and former police officer Lee Harris in the ''My Roanoke Nightmare'' documentary, and she reprised her role as Marie Laveau in a guest role in the eighth season ''[[American Horror Story: Apocalypse|Apocalypse]]''. In 2018, Bassett began producing and starring in the [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]] [[first responder]] drama series ''[[9-1-1 (TV series)|9-1-1]]'', playing [[LAPD]] patrol sergeant Athena Grant.
==Early life and education== Bassett was born on August 16, 1958 in New York City, the daughter of Betty Jane (née Gilbert; 1935–2014)<ref>[http://www.legacy.com/obituaries/sptimes/obituary.aspx?pid=171499429 Betty Bassett Obituary Tampa Bay Times] accessed November 23, 2016</ref> and Daniel Benjamin Bassett (1924–1981),<ref name='DBB-Grave'>{{cite web |url=https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/139572184 |title=Daniel Benjamin Bassett, Jr. |author=<!--Not stated--> |date= |website=Find A Grave |publisher= |access-date=August 4, 2018 |quote=}}</ref> and was raised in Harlem.<ref>Bassett, Angela (2009), p. 11.</ref><ref name=friends>{{cite book | url = http://www.faithfulreader.com/reviews/0373830580-excerpt.asp| title=Friends: A Love Story | first=Angela | last=Bassett |first2= Courtney B.|last2= Vance|first3= Hilary| last3= with Beard|publisher=Kimani Press (excerpt via) Faithful Reader.com| isbn=9780373830589| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070624211656/http://faithfulreader.com/reviews/0373830580-excerpt.asp| archivedate=June 24, 2007|quote=...she met my daddy, Daniel Benjamin Bassett, who'd moved to New York from Winston-Salem, North Carolina. They met, dated, got pregnant with me, married and lived in a small apartment in Harlem.}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Betty Jane BASSETT|url=http://www.legacy.com/obituaries/sptimes/obituary.aspx?pid=171499429|publisher=legacy.com|accessdate=September 19, 2014| archivedate= November 29, 2014 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141129024057/http://www.legacy.com/obituaries/sptimes/obituary.aspx?pid=171499429 | deadurl=no}}</ref> Bassett's middle name was given to her in honor of her aunt Evelyn.<ref name=friends /> The origin of the Bassett surname comes from her ancestor William Henry Bassett, who took the surname of his former oppressor.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://genealogymagazine.blogspot.com/2014/10/nas-angela-bassett-and-valerie-jarrett.html |title=Nas, Angela Bassett, and Valerie Jarrett on 'Finding Your Roots' |work=Genealogy Magazine |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141202225855/http://genealogymagazine.blogspot.com/2014/10/nas-angela-bassett-and-valerie-jarrett.html |archivedate=December 2, 2014 |date= |accessdate=October 1, 2018}}</ref> Ten months after Bassett was born, her mother became pregnant and had a second child, Bassett's sister D'nette. Bassett said the pregnancy "only made things harder." Bassett's parents "shipped" her to stay with her father's sister Golden. While her aunt did not have any children of her own, she "loved children, and she was good with them."<ref name=Bassett12>Bassett, Angela (2009), pp. 12-13.</ref>
After her parents' separation, she relocated from [[Winston-Salem, North Carolina]] to [[St. Petersburg, Florida]], where she and her sister D'nette were raised by their social worker/civil servant mother.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.filmreference.com/film/9/Angela-Bassett.html |title=Angela Bassett Biography (1958–) |publisher=Filmreference.com |date= |accessdate=August 7, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Weinraub |first=Bernard |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9F0CEFDC1E3FF930A15755C0A965958260 |title=As Tina Turner, Wig to High Heels – |work=The New York Times |date=June 23, 1993 |accessdate=August 7, 2010}}</ref> Bassett did not see her father again for several years, until she attended her grandmother's funeral. There, Bassett met his daughter from his first marriage, Jean, who at twelve years old, was several years older than Bassett.<ref name="Bassett18-19" /> After graduating from Jordan Park Elementary School, she began being bused out of her neighborhood to attend Disston Middle School for seventh grade. The year she began attending was 1970, the first year busing was implemented to integrate public schools in St. Petersburg. After completing seventh grade, she was bused to Azalea Middle School for eighth and ninth grade. Bassett's mother became more involved in her daughter's grades and told her and her sister the pair were going to college.<ref>Bassett, Angela (2009), pp. 23-24.</ref>
In her younger years, Bassett was "in love" with the [[Jackson 5]] and dreamed of marrying a member of the family group, stating it would probably be "whoever had the cutest, roundest Afro at the time. In my imagination we would have children and live in a real house."<ref name="Bassett18-19">Bassett, Angela (2009), pp. 18-19.</ref> As her interest in entertainment developed, Angela and her sister would often put on shows, reading poems or performing popular music for their family.<ref name=Bassett29 />
[[File:Boca Ciega High School.JPG|thumb|right|[[Boca Ciega High School]], where Bassett as a teenager was a member of the debate team and student government among other endeavors.]] At [[Boca Ciega High School]], Bassett was a cheerleader and a member of the [[Upward Bound]] college prep program, the debate team, student government, drama club and choir. A straight "A" and "B" student for the most part, Bassett got her first "C," in physical education, and tried to get her mother to not feel disappointment in the grade. Bassett called the grade the "average," leading her mother to say that she did not have "average kids." As Bassett described, a "sense of pride" developed in her and she did not get another "C" until college.<ref name="Oprah.com" /> During high school, Bassett became the first African-American from Boca Ciega to be admitted to the National Honor Society. She participated in Upward Bound, an academic and cultural enrichment program for underprivileged students. Bassett says she and the other participants did not see themselves as underprivileged.<ref name=Bassett29>Bassett, Angela (2009), pp. 29-31.</ref>
Bassett attended [[Yale University]] and received her B.A. degree in [[African-American studies]] in 1980. In 1983, she earned a [[Master of Fine Arts]] degree from the [[Yale School of Drama]], despite opposition from her father's sister who warned her to not "waste" her "Yale education on theater." She was the only member of Bassett's family to have gone to both college and graduate school.<ref name="Oprah.com">{{cite news|url=http://www.oprah.com/spirit/Angela-Bassetts-Aha-Moment|title=Angela Bassett's Aha! Moment|publisher=Oprah.com|date=September 2008}}</ref> At Yale, Bassett met her future husband [[Courtney B. Vance]], a 1986 graduate of the drama school. Bassett was also classmates with actor [[Charles S. Dutton]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.sfltimes.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=15284&Itemid=331|title=Celebrities, Community Activists Put Gun Violence in the Spotlight|date=January 23, 2014|work=South Florida Times|first=Erick|last=Johnson}}</ref>
After graduation, Bassett worked as a receptionist for a beauty salon and as a photo researcher. Bassett soon looked for acting work in the New York theater. One of her first New York performances came in 1985 when she appeared in [[J. E. Franklin]]'s ''Black Girl'' at [[Second Stage Theatre]]. She appeared in two [[August Wilson]] plays at the [[Yale Repertory Theatre]] under the direction of her long-time instructor [[Lloyd Richards]]. The Wilson plays featuring Bassett were ''[[Ma Rainey's Black Bottom]]'' (1984) and ''[[Joe Turner's Come and Gone]]'' (1986). In 2006, she had the opportunity to work on the Wilson canon again, starring in ''[[Fences (play)|Fences]]'' alongside longtime collaborator [[Laurence Fishburne]] at the [[Pasadena Playhouse]] in California.
In 2018, Basset was awarded an [[honorary doctoral degree]] in fine arts from her alma mater, Yale University.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.essence.com/celebrity/angela-bassett-honorary-degree-yale|title=Angela Bassett Is Now Dr. Angela Bassett After Receiving Honorary Degree From Yale|work=Essence.com|access-date=May 22, 2018|language=en}}</ref>
==Career==
===Early work=== In 1985, Bassett made her first television appearance as a prostitute in the TV movie ''Doubletake''. She made her film debut as a news reporter in ''[[F/X]]'' (1986), for which she was required to join the [[Screen Actors Guild]] (SAG).<ref name=TVGuide>"How Did You Get Your SAG-AFTRA Card?" ''[[TV Guide]]''. January 13, 2014. p. 10.</ref> Bassett moved to Los Angeles in 1988 for more acting jobs<ref name=NewYorkTimes /> and gained recognition in the films ''[[Boyz n the Hood]]'' (1991) and ''[[Malcolm X (1992 film)|Malcolm X]]'' (1992). For her portrayal of [[Betty Shabazz]], she earned an [[NAACP Image Award|Image Award]]. Despite the award, the movie was not entirely given positive reception, being referred to by critics as failing to "capture" the rage of [[Autobiography of Malcolm X|Malcolm X's autobiography]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/1993-07-23/entertainment/9307210869_1_autobiography-of-malcolm-malcolm-x-born-malcolm|title='X' Fails To Capture Rage Of Autobiography|date=July 23, 1993|work=Orlando Sentinel|first=Jay|last=Boyar}}</ref> During production of ''Malcolm X'', Spike Lee showed Bassett a tape of the exact moment when Malcolm X was shot during his assassination, since they would be filming the scene. Bassett called the recording "haunting", but noted that after listening, she was "able to grab hold of the pain and re-create the scene." Bassett felt it was important for her to get the assassination scene correct, and wondered how Betty "found the strength to keep going, to raise her family, to educate, to sustain them."<ref>Bassett, Angela, (2009), pp. 154–155.</ref> ''Malcolm X'' was released on November 18, 1992.
===1990s=== In 1992, Bassett played [[Katherine Jackson]] in ''[[The Jacksons: An American Dream]]''. Bassett's agents tried to discourage her from playing the role, given the negative reception that [[Michael Jackson]] had. She admitted to not caring about the negative view of members of the Jackson family at the time, citing her childhood fondness of the group as an example of her passion for the project and believed her "instinct" about the role had been correct once learning of the positive reviews the miniseries received after airing.<ref>Bassett, Angela (2009), pp. 152–153.</ref> Bassett had previously idolized the group growing up and said the Jackson family were positive influences on the African-American community for their successes. Bassett had previously worried that after her role as Betty Shabazz in ''Malcolm X'', she would not find another role "as satisfying". Bassett at the time of the film's release expressed her belief that her career would never receive such high-profile roles again. "I think I have been incredibly blessed and it is probably just all downhill from here."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1992-11-15/news/tv-621_1_katherine-jackson|title=Her 'American Dream': Angela Bassett Says Playing the Mother of the Jackson's Was Emotional and Uplifting|date=November 15, 1992|first=Susan|last=King|work=Los Angeles Times}}</ref>
Later that year, Bassett was cast as [[Tina Turner]] in ''[[What's Love Got to Do with It (film)|What's Love Got to Do with It]]'' (1993).<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/movie/review?res=9F0CE4D71539F93AA35755C0A965958260|title=Review/Film: What's Love Got to Do With It; Tina Turner's Tale: Living Life With Ike and Then Without Him|first=Janet|last=Maslin|date=June 9, 1993|publisher=''The New York Times''}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://ew.com/article/1993/06/25/whats-love-got-do-it-2/|title='What's Love Got to Do With It': EW review|first=Owen|last=Gleiberman|date=June 25, 1993|publisher=Entertainment Weekly}}</ref> Bassett returned to Los Angeles after ''Malcolm X'' filming was completed, and got a call for an audition for a movie based on ''[[I, Tina]]'', Tina Turner's memoir.<ref>Bassett, Angela, (2009), p. 156.</ref> Bassett won a [[Golden Globe]] and earned an [[Academy Award for Best Actress|Academy Award]] nomination for her portrayal of Turner. She was the first African-American to win the [[Golden Globe Award for Best Actress – Motion Picture Musical or Comedy]]. Bassett obtained the role after beating [[Halle Berry]] and [[Robin Givens]], but only had a month to prepare before filming began. She met Tina Turner twice, and was given advice by the woman she would be portraying from wigs and outfits to dancing styles. Turner also did Bassett's make up, leading Bassett to call her "supportive" and her "biggest fan."<ref name=NewYorkTimes>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1993/06/23/movies/as-tina-turner-wig-to-high-heels.html|title=As Tina Turner, Wig to High Heels|date=June 23, 1993|first=Bernard|last=Weinraub|work=The New York Times}}</ref> Bassett described to the ''[[Orlando Sentinel]]'' going to one of Turner's concerts and crying profusely. According to Bassett, upon realizing that she knew some of Turner's dance moves, she was "almost a river of tears."<ref name=OSBassett1995 /> Marc Bernardin of ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' wrote that Bassett "gave the performance of a lifetime" portraying Turner in the biopic.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.ew.com/ew/gallery/0,,20483133_20649427_21244221,00.html|title=47. What's Love Got To Do With It (1993) Subject: Tina Turner|date=April 12, 2013|publisher=EW.com|first=Marc|last=Bernardin}}</ref> [[File:Angela Bassett.jpg|thumb|Bassett at the [[NABOB Awards]], 1996]] Bassett starred in three movies in 1995, which were released with varied reactions from critics: ''[[Vampire in Brooklyn]]'', ''[[Strange Days (film)|Strange Days]]'', and ''[[Waiting to Exhale]]'' (where she worked with author [[Terry McMillan]]). In ''Strange Days'', Bassett played Lornette "Mace" Mason, a chauffeur and bodyguard. In ''Vampire in Brooklyn'', she played Rita Veder, a tortured cop with a dark secret. She was excited to work with [[Eddie Murphy]] in ''Vampire in Brooklyn'', as well as director [[Wes Craven]]. Bassett had previously worked with Craven on television shows.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://articles.mcall.com/1995-10-22/entertainment/3067471_1_vampire-portrayal-of-tina-turner-strange-days|title=Angela Bassett Sticks Out Her Neck|date=October 22, 1995|first=Paul|last=Willistein|work=Morning Call}}</ref> Bassett's character in ''Waiting to Exhale'', Bernadine Harris, was betrayed by her husband and in revenge she set fire to his entire wardrobe and vehicle, then sold what was left for one dollar. Bassett described the then-recently filmed party scene and her character in ''Waiting to Exhale'' to the ''Orlando Sentinel''. Bassett said, "The thing is that my character is thinking about how her husband has left her. I have a cigarette in one hand, and I'm drinking. Basically, the four of us are sitting there talking about men and having some fun."<ref name=OSBassett1995>{{cite news|url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/1995-12-22/features/9512210048_1_angela-bassett-tears-tina-turner|title=Tough Angela Bassett Is A Real Softy|date=December 22, 1995|work=Orlando Sentinel}}</ref>
In 1997, she starred as the President's advisor in ''[[Contact (1997 American film)|Contact]]''.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/06/movies/using-a-big-budget-to-ask-big-questions.html|title=Using a Big Budget To Ask Big Questions|date=July 6, 1997|first=Bernard|last=Weinraub|work=The New York Times}}</ref> Stephen Holden of ''The New York Times'' opinioned that Bassett was "largely wasted as a Presidential assistant."<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/movie/review?res=9907E1DA1039F932A25754C0A961958260|title=Which Route Upward, On a Wing or a Prayer?|first=Stephen|last=Holden|date=July 11, 1997|work=The New York Times}}</ref>
In 1998, [[Fatboy Slim]] sampled Bassett's voice from 1995's ''[[Strange Days (film)|Strange Days]]'', specifically the line ''"this is your life, right here, right now!"'', for his hit single "[[Right Here, Right Now (Fatboy Slim song)|Right Here, Right Now]]". Also in 1998, Bassett starred in ''[[How Stella Got Her Groove Back]]'', once again collaborating with McMillan. She played Stella, a 40-year-old American professional woman who falls in love with a 20-year-old Jamaican man. She received praise for the performance,<ref>{{cite news|url=https://variety.com/1998/film/reviews/how-stella-got-her-groove-back-1200454761/|title=Review: ‘How Stella Got Her Groove Back’|first=Todd|last=McCarthy|date=August 10, 1998|publisher=Variety|quote=The dazzling Bassett is a delight to watch throughout, and obligingly plays second banana to Goldberg whenever the latter turns up to steal any and every scene she wants.}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/style/longterm/movies/videos/howstellagothergroovebackkempley.htm|title='Stella': Chiffon in the Sun|first=Rita|last=Kempley|publisher=Washington Post|quote=If Bassett weren't so dazzling, Diggs weren't so charismatic and Goldberg weren't so brassy, Stella's groove might seem unworthy of our attention. Regina King, the football star's supportive wife in "Jerry Maguire," is also a treat as the saucier of Stella's two sisters.}}</ref> Stephen Holden of ''[[The New York Times]]'' calling Bassett's character "the best thing in the movie" and writing that Bassett "portrays this high-strung superwoman with such intensity that she makes her almost believable."<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/movie/review?res=9C04E6DD133AF937A2575BC0A96E958260|title=How Stella Got Her Groove Back (1998)|first=Stephen|last=Holden|work=The New York Times}}</ref>
In 1999, Bassett starred in ''[[Music of the Heart]]'', once again collaborating with horror icon [[Wes Craven]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.csmonitor.com/1999/1029/p20s1.html |title=The drama behind 'Music of the Heart'|first=Bonnie|last=Churchill|date=October 29, 1999}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1999/10/27/nyregion/to-celebrate-music-teacher-film-toughened-up-school.html|title=To Celebrate Music Teacher, Film Toughened Up School|first=Anemona|last=Hartocollis|date=October 27, 1999|work=The New York Times}}</ref> Matthew Eng wrote of her "terrifically specific chemistry" with [[Meryl Streep]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://tribecafilm.com/stories/music-of-the-heart-wes-craven-meryl-streep-miramax|title=Let's Stop Treating MUSIC OF THE HEART as the Forgettable Footnote in Wes Craven’s Career|date=September 1, 2015|first=Matthew|last=Eng|publisher=tribecafilm.com}}</ref>
===2000s=== In 2000, Bassett turned down the lead role in ''[[Monster's Ball]]'' because of the script's sexual content; the role earned [[Halle Berry]] the [[Academy Award for Best Actress]]. The first film Bassett appeared in that year was ''[[Supernova (2000 film)|Supernova]]'', where she played a medical officer.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.empireonline.com/movies/supernova/review/|title=Supernova Review|first=Kim|last=Newman|publisher=Empire}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://amarillo.com/stories/011800/ent_plot.shtml|title=Talent of cast wasted on 'Supernova' plot|date=January 18, 2000|first=Chip|last=Chandler|publisher=Armarillo.com}}</ref> Her other two films released in 2000 were ''[[Whispers: An Elephant's Tale]]'' and ''[[Boesman and Lena]]''. Todd McCarthy of ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' wrote that in ''Boesman and Lena'' Bassett "abandons her recently cultivated glamorous image to dig to the core of Lena’s fierce, probing, contentious, compassionate character."<ref>{{cite news|url=https://variety.com/2000/film/reviews/boesman-lena-1200462300/|title=Review: ‘Boesman & Lena’|date=May 15, 2000|work=Variety|first=Todd|last=McCarthy}}</ref> Kevin Thomas of the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' wrote Bassett captured all of her character's "mercurial mood swings" and both Bassett and her costar [[Danny Glover]] "rise to the challenge of these larger-than-life roles, just as you would expect."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2000/nov/17/entertainment/ca-53045|title=Gripping 'Boesman & Lena' Propelled by Glover, Bassett|date=November 17, 2000|work=Los Angeles Times|first=Kevin|last=Thomas}}</ref>
She appeared in the 2001 film ''[[The Score (2001 film)|The Score]]''. Her character was in a relationship with [[Robert De Niro]]'s. She read the film's script and became interested. She was then telephoned by director Frank Oz, who told her Robert De Niro would "like to meet with you". Bassett met with De Niro and later realized the conversation was meant to break the ice before they started filming.<ref name=TheGuardian2001>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2001/sep/29/features|date=September 29, 2001|work=The Guardian|first=David|last=Emer|title=Angela's assets}}</ref> In addition to ''The Score'', that year she also had a role in the television film ''Ruby's Bucket of Blood''. The following year, in 2002, Bassett acted in ''[[Sunshine State (film)|Sunshine State]]'' and ''[[The Rosa Parks Story]]''. In ''The Rosa Parks Story'', Bassett was cast as [[Rosa Parks]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2002-02-22/features/0202220010_1_rosa-parks-story-angela-bassett-movie|date=February 22, 2002|work=Chicago Tribune|first=Steve|last=Johnson|title=Angela Bassett blossoms in `Rosa Parks Story'}}</ref> Laura Fries of ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' wrote that Bassett "takes her physical strength and turns it inward to portray Parks" and expressed her belief that "lesser hands" would allow for misinterpretation or gross underplay of Parks' personality.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://variety.com/2002/tv/reviews/the-rosa-parks-story-1200551203/|title=The Rosa Parks Story|work=Variety|date=February 21, 2002|first=Laura|last=Fries}}</ref> In addition to positive reception of her role, Bassett was seen as the "star" of the film due to playing the lead and earned a nomination for a [[Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Lead Actress in a Miniseries or a Movie]] for her performance.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.hollywood.com/static/tv-review-the-rosa-parks-story|title=The Rosa Parks Story|publisher=Hollywood.com}}</ref>
In 2003, she read from the WPA slave narratives in ''[[Unchained Memories]]''. In the 1930s, about 100,000 former slaves were still living during the Great Depression, of which 2,300 were interviewed part of the Federal Writers' Project. The transcripts of the Slave Narratives collection of the Library of Congress is a record of slavery, bondage and misery.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://variety.com/2003/tv/reviews/unchained-memories-readings-from-the-slave-narratives-1200543545/|title=Review: ‘Unchained Memories: Readings From the Slave Narratives’|first=Laura|last=Fries|date=February 9, 2003|publisher=Variety}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dvdtalk.com/reviews/7091/unchained-memories-readings-from-the-slave-narratives/|title=Unchained Memories: Readings from the Slave Narratives|first=Gil|last=Jawetz|date=August 2, 2003|publisher=dvdtalk.com}}</ref> That year she also appeared in the film ''[[Masked and Anonymous]]'', playing a mistress.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://old.post-gazette.com/movies/20031128masked1128fnp4.asp|title='Masked and Anonymous' |first=Scott|last=Mervis|date=November 28, 2003|publisher=Gazette}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2003/jul/25/entertainment/et-masked25|title=A self-indulgent 'Masked' has more tedium than allegory|date=July 25, 2003|first=Kevin|last=Thomas|publisher=Los Angeles Times}}</ref> Ann Hornaday noted her as among the "endless parade of actors who show up even for the briefest of appearances".<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2003/09/05/AR2005040200611.html|first=Ann|last=Hornaday|title='Masked': Riddled With Dylan|date=September 5, 2003|publisher=Washington Post}}</ref>
In 2004, she had roles in the films ''[[The Lazarus Child]]'' and ''[[Mr. 3000]]''. ''Mr. 3000'' was a comedy in which Bassett costarred with [[Bernie Mac]]. When asked if the film was much easier to act in than the more intense roles she had in the past, Bassett responded, "This was much easier. This was a walk in the park. It was pretty easy compared to some of the roles Ive done that call for so much emotion or physicality." At the time of the film's release, she called both Bernie Mac and [[Laurence Fishburne]], who she had worked with in the past, her "favorites" and said the pair were both "highly professional and extraordinarily talented."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://movies.about.com/od/mr3000/a/mr3000ab090204.htm|title=Angela Bassett Talks Sports and 'Mr. 3000'|publisher=movies.about.com|first=Rebecca|last=Murray}}</ref> The only film she appeared in during the following year was ''[[Mr. and Mrs. Smith (2005 film)|Mr. and Mrs. Smith]]'' in an uncredited voice role.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://movieweb.com/angela-bassett-and-keith-david-join-mr-and-mrs-smith/|title=Angela Bassett and Keith David join Mr. and Mrs. Smith|first=Brian|last=B.|publisher=movieweb.com|date=September 8, 2004}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://variety.com/2004/film/markets-festivals/bassett-david-join-smith-1117910067/|title=Bassett, David join ‘Smith’|first=Dave|last=McNary|date=September 7, 2004|publisher=Variety}}</ref>
[[File:Angela Bassett, Red Dress Collection 2007.jpg|thumb|left|upright|Bassett at the 2007 The Heart Truth's Red Dress Collection.]] In the 2006 film ''[[Akeelah and the Bee]]'', Bassett portrayed Tanya Anderson, the mother of the film's lead, Akeelah, played by [[Keke Palmer]]. Bassett said she loved the story,<ref name=blackfilm.com /> viewing the lead character as someone that "could be anyone because each of us have had dreams and aspirations and wanting to be and needing to be supported and directed",<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=5368501|title=Angela Bassett and 'Akeelah and the Bee'|date=April 28, 2006|publisher=npr.org}}</ref> and described working with Palmer as being "really wonderful." According to Bassett, the two bonded and that Palmer was as good an actress as any adult she had worked with.<ref name=blackfilm.com>{{cite news|url=http://www.blackfilm.com/20060421/features/angelabassett.shtml|title=Akeelah and the Bee: An Interview with Angela Bassett|date=April 2006|first=Wilson|last=Morales}}</ref> Bassett appeared in the television film ''[[Time Bomb (television film)|Time Bomb]]'' the same year. Her role was seen as just an "extended cameo" by Brian Lowry of ''Variety''.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://variety.com/2006/tv/reviews/time-bomb-1200517664/|title=Time Bomb|work=Variety|first=Brian|last=Lowry|date=March 12, 2006}}</ref>
Bassett provided her voice for the 2007 film ''[[Meet the Robinsons]]''.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2007/apr/01/animation.family|title=Meet the Robinsons|first=Philip|last=French|date=April 1, 2007|publisher=The Guardian}}</ref> When asked about her motives in taking on the role, Bassett said, "For one, it was a character I had never played before, which is always important to me, to keep me sharp. But it was also the desire to be part of a well-written movie that has something really positive to say about families and about all the different ways there can be to make a family."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.popmatters.com/article/angela-bassett-makes-a-leap-with-meet-the-robinsons/|title=Angela Bassett makes a leap with 'Meet the Robinsons'|date=March 30, 2007|first=Terry|last=Lawson|publisher=popmatters.com}}</ref>
She appeared in the 2008 film ''[[Gospel Hill]]''.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://variety.com/2009/film/reviews/gospel-hill-1200475538/|title=Review: 'Gospel Hill' |date=August 24, 2009|publisher=Variety|first=Ronnie|last=Scheib}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/review/gospel-hill-126077|title=Gospel Hill|first=Duane|last=Byrge|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]}}</ref> Stephen Holden of ''The New York Times'' wrote Bassett's "fiery self-possession brings a spark of passion to her stick-figure character".<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/08/28/movies/28gospel.html|title=A Quiet Little Town With an Unsolved Murder and Greedy Developers|date=August 27, 2009|first=Stephen|last=Holden}}</ref> She next appeared in ''Of Boys and Men'', portraying Rieta Cole, the matriarch of a Chicago family who is killed in an accident in the beginning of the film and is seen through flashbacks for the remainder of the film. She and her costars [[Robert Townsend (actor)|Robert Townsend]] and [[Victoria Rowell]] were seen by Robert Gillard of ''LA Sentinel'' as doing wonderful jobs of "capturing the emotions of a family stricken by grief."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://lasentinel.net/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=2926:movie-review-of-boys-and-men&catid=60&Itemid=150|title=Movie Review: 'Of Boys and Men'|work=LA Sentinel|first=Robert|last=Gillard|date=February 7, 2011}}</ref> Bassett also had a role in [[Nothing but the Truth (2008 American film)|Nothing But the Truth]] in 2008.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.movieweb.com/angela-bassett-seeks-nothing-but-the-truth#|title=Angela Bassett Seeks Nothing But the Truth|date=October 21, 2007|work=MovieWeb|access-date=June 15, 2018|language=en-US}}</ref> Bassett joined the regular cast of ''[[ER (TV series)|ER]]'' for the show's final season (2008–2009).<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/angela-bassett-at-er-110357|title=Angela Bassett in at 'ER'|first=Nellie|last=Andreeva|work=The Hollywood Reporter|date=April 27, 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.today.com/popculture/angela-bassett-join-final-season-er-wbna24356230|title=Angela Bassett to join final season of ‘ER’|date=April 28, 2008|publisher=Today.com}}</ref> She portrayed [[Catherine Banfield|Dr. Catherine Banfield]], an exacting Chief of the ER who was also working to recover from the death of a son and to bring another child into her family. Bassett's husband Courtney Vance played her television husband on ''ER'' as Russell Banfield.
In the 2009 film ''[[Notorious (2009 film)|Notorious]]'', Bassett portrayed Voletta Wallace, the mother of [[The Notorious B.I.G.]]<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-bassett-idUSTRE5074CM20090108|title=Just A Minute With: Angela Bassett on "Notorious"|publisher=Reuters|date=January 8, 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://thesource.com/2015/05/15/flashback-friday-angela-bassett-talks-notorious-w-the-source/|title=Flashback Friday: Angela Bassett Talks ‘Notorious’ w/ The Source|date=May 15, 2015|publisher=The Source}}</ref> To portray Wallace's Jamaican accent, Bassett conversed with her on and off the film set, and she practiced her accent using tapes that Wallace made.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/1601426/notorious-actress-angela-bassett-says-biggies-mom-is-fascinating/|date=December 16, 2008|first=Shaheem|last=Reid|title=‘Notorious’ Actress Angela Bassett Says Biggie’s Mom Is ‘Fascinating|publisher=MTV}}</ref> Bassett said she jumped at the chance to be part of the film after reading the script. She felt it did a "wonderful job of bringing" The Notorious B.I.G.'s "life to the page."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.hollywood.com/news/movies/5222217/angela-bassett-to-play-notorious-b-i-g-s-mom|title=Angela Bassett to Play Notorious B.I.G.'S Mom|date=April 21, 2008|publisher=Hollywood.com}}</ref> Bassett earned positive reviews for her performance in the film, noted as being one of the more experienced actors involved.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/01/16/movies/16noto.html|title=The Tale of Biggie Smalls, Writ Larger Than Life|work=The New York Times|date=January 16, 2009|first=A. O.|last=Scott}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2009/jan/16/entertainment/et-fave16|title=Angela Bassett of 'Notorious'|date=January 16, 2009|work=Los Angeles Times|first=Charlie|last=Amter}}</ref>
===2010s=== In 2010, Bassett lent her voice to portray [[Michelle Obama|First Lady Michelle Obama]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.foxflash.com/div.php/main/page?aID=1z2z2z176z3z5 |title=FoxFlash |publisher=FoxFlash |date= |accessdate=August 7, 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100824000852/http://foxflash.com/div.php/main/page?aID=1z2z2z176z3z5 |archivedate=August 24, 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> on an episode of ''[[The Simpsons]]'' titled "[[Stealing First Base]]". Bassett was seen as a "terrific" fill in for Obama.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.thehollywoodgossip.com/2010/03/michelle-obama-visits-the-simpsons/|title=Michelle Obama Visits The Simpsons|date=March 22, 2010|work=The Hollywood Gossip}}</ref> Bassett was also cast in the superhero film ''[[Green Lantern (film)|Green Lantern]]'', released in 2011, as notable [[DC Comics]] character [[Amanda Waller]].<ref>{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1118016867.html?categoryid=13&cs=1&nid=2562 |title=Angela Bassett joins 'Green Lantern' Cast |work=Variety |date=March 24, 2010 |accessdate=August 7, 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100728232915/http://www.variety.com/article/VR1118016867.html?categoryid=13&cs=1&nid=2562| archivedate= July 28, 2010 | deadurl= no}}</ref> Bassett said working on the film was "a lot of fun" and that she enjoyed being a part of it.<ref name=BETJumpingTheBroom /> Despite this, Bassett was taken "out of her element" with the arrangements made that accommodated the computer-generated effects. She called it her first time doing "this kind of movie" but expressed interest in seeing what her scenes looked like.<ref name=nationalpost2011 /> In 2010, ''[[Deadline Hollywood]]'' reported that Bassett would have a role in ''[[One Police Plaza]]''.<ref name="tvguide1">{{cite web|url= http://www.tvguide.com/News/Angela-Bassett-Cast-1025750.aspx|title= Angela Bassett Cast in ABC's One Police Plaza|publisher=TVGuide.com|accessdate=November 18, 2010}}</ref> In 2011, Bassett co-starred with [[Samuel L. Jackson]] in the play ''[[The Mountaintop]]'' a fictionalized depiction of the night before the assassination of Dr. Martin Luther King (Jackson portrays MLK) while at the Lorraine Motel. The critically acclaimed play by [[Katori Hall]] originally debuted in London's West End in 2009 and went on to win the [[Laurence Olivier Award]] for Best New Play. The production opened on Broadway on October 13, 2011. In March 2011, it was reported that Bassett had signed up for a lead role in the ABC pilot ''Identity''.<ref>{{cite news|first=Morgan|last=Jeffery|url=http://www.digitalspy.com/tv/news/a306882/angela-bassett-signs-for-identity.html|title=Angela Bassett signs for 'Identity'|publisher=Digital Spy|date=March 3, 2011}}</ref>
She also appeared in the 2011 film ''[[Jumping the Broom]]'', playing the matriarch of a wealthy family.<ref>{{cite news |url= http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/gossip/2011/05/jumping-the-broom-premiere-laz-alonso-romeo-paula-patton-angela-bassett.html |title= 'Jumping the Broom': Laz Alonso, Paula Patton, Angela Bassett, Romeo head down the aisle at Hollywood premiere |first= Christie |last=D'Zurilla |date= May 5, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.philly.com/philly/columnists/20110506__Jumping_the_Broom___Set-to_at_a_family_wedding.html |title= 'Jumping the Broom': Set-to at a family wedding |date=May 9, 2011 |first=Carrie |last=Rickey |publisher= Philly.com}}</ref> Bassett had a good feeling about the film from "the start",<ref name=nationalpost2011>{{cite news|url=http://arts.nationalpost.com/2011/05/06/angela-bassett-gets-the-green-light-to-jump-the-broom/ |title=Angela Bassett gets the Green light to Jump the Broom |date=May 6, 2011 |work=National Post |first=Bob |last=Thompson |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20140908205856/http://arts.nationalpost.com/2011/05/06/angela-bassett-gets-the-green-light-to-jump-the-broom/ |archivedate=September 8, 2014 }}</ref> and believed her character had a "real presence" in the film and felt she was active in the plot.<ref name=BETJumpingTheBroom>{{cite news|url=http://www.bet.com/news/celebrities/2011/05/05/q-a-angela-bassett-talks-jumping-the-broom-and-upcoming-projects.html|title=Q&A: Angela Bassett Talks "Jumping the Broom"|first=Ronke Idowu|last=Reeves|date=May 4, 2011|publisher=BET}}</ref> Bassett's and [[Loretta Devine]]'s performances in the film were called "in some ways too fierce for the room, offering nuances of hostility and hurt that the movie cannot really handle" and contributing to the "unevenness of the performances" in the film.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/05/06/movies/jumping-the-broom-with-angela-bassett-review.html|work=The New York Times|date=May 5, 2011|title=New York Times review of 'Jumping the Broom'}}</ref> Bassett and Devine were noted as "superb, distinguished actresses" by Kirk Honeycutt of ''The Hollywood Reporter'', but were seen as having been "asked to overdo every moment with permanent scowls and body language more suitable to ''[[Mortal Kombat]]''."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/review/jumping-broom-review-183310|title=Jumping the Broom: Review|date=April 28, 2011|first=Kirk|last=Honeycutt}}</ref> Despite this, her performance was given some positive attention, with Elizabeth Weitzman of ''New York Daily News'' saying Bassett "makes the movie hers".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/tv-movies/jumping-broom-review-loretta-devine-angela-bassett-sweep-attention-article-1.140883|title='Jumping the Broom' review: Loretta Devine, Angela Bassett sweep up the attention|work=New York Daily News|date=May 6, 2011}}</ref> The film was Bassett's second time working with Devine, as the pair had worked together previously in ''Waiting to Exhale''.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.hitfix.com/articles/watch-jumping-the-broom-brings-angela-bassett-and-loretta-devine-together-again|title='Jumping the Broom' brings Angela Bassett and Loretta Devine together again|publisher=hitfix.com|date=May 6, 2011|first=Gregory|last=Ellwood}}</ref> Director Salim Akil said Bassett's presence quietly makes a big difference.<ref name=nationalpost2011 />
Bassett was featured in the 2012 film ''[[This Means War (film)|This Means War]]'',<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.empireonline.com/movies/news/angela-bassett-says-means-war/|title=Angela Basset Says This Means War|first=James|last=White|date=November 29, 2010|publisher=empireonline.com}}</ref> having been known to be attached to the film since two years prior.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://variety.com/2010/film/news/angela-bassett-set-for-role-in-this-means-war-1118028041/|title=Fox's McG-directed action comedy centers on CIA|date=November 29, 2010|first=Dave|last=McNary|work=Variety}}</ref> Tambay A. Obenson of [[IndieWire]] attributed Bassett's lack of appearances in promotional material to her having a small role and her demographic not being targeted by the film.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.indiewire.com/2012/02/angela-bassett-talks-about-her-character-in-this-means-war-yes-shes-in-it-234915/|title=Angela Bassett Talks About Her Character In "This Means War" (Yes, She’s In It)|date=February 4, 2012|first=Tambay A.|last=Obenson|publisher=IndieWire}}</ref> Bassett also appeared as herself in ''I Ain't Scared Of You''.
Bassett portrayed [[Coretta Scott King]] in the television film ''[[Betty and Coretta]]'', which aired on February 2, 2013, continuing her trend of portraying real women.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/therootdc/post/betty-and-coretta-debunking-the-drama-in-lifetimes-tv-movie-about-the-two-widowed-legends/2013/02/01/1b7344f0-6c78-11e2-8740-9b58f43c191a_blog.html |title=Betty and Coretta: Debunking the drama in Lifetime’s TV movie about the two widowed legends|first=Barbara|last=Reynolds|publisher=Washington Post}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://variety.com/2013/tv/reviews/betty-coretta-1117949126/|title=Betty & Coretta|date=January 30, 2013|first=Brian|last=Lowry|publisher=Variety}}</ref> Bassett had previously played Shabazz in both ''Malcolm X'' and ''[[Panther (film)|Panther]]'', but instead played [[Coretta Scott King]] opposite to [[Mary J. Blige]], who played Shabazz. Bassett was surprised to learn after researching that Coretta initially refused [[Martin Luther King, Jr.]]'s "advances" and called Mrs. King a "modern day iconic heroine." While being asked about what drew her to play real-life women, Bassett answered "The respect that I have for their lives—their stories, vulnerabilities, strength, and resolve."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.biography.com/blog/angela-bassett-betty-coretta-became-sisters-through-tragedy-21113997|title=Angela Bassett: ‘Betty & Coretta’ Became Sisters Through Tragedy|publisher=Biography.com|date=February 1, 2013|first=Eudie|last=Pak}}</ref> Bassett began filming her scenes during the latter part of the previous year.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/lifetime-betty-coretta-angela-bassett-coretta-scott-king-mary-j-blige-lifetime-364995|title=Bassett to Play Coretta Scott King in Lifetime Movie|work=The Hollywood Reporter|date=August 23, 2012}}</ref> [[Mary J. Blige]], when asked about what kind of experience it was to work with Bassett, said that she was "one of Angela's biggest fans" while calling her an "amazing woman."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.blackfilm.com/read/2013/01/angela-bassett-mary-j-blige-talk-betty-and-coretta/|title=Angela Bassett, Mary J. Blige talk ‘Betty & Coretta’|date=January 29, 2013|first=Wilson|last=Morales|publisher=Black Film}}</ref> The film received mix reviews, including negative reactions from [[Ilyasah Shabazz]] and [[Bernice King]], the daughters of [[Betty Shabazz]] and Coretta Scott King.
Bassett recently appeared as Secret Service director Lynne Jacobs in the action thriller ''[[Olympus Has Fallen]]'', released in March 22, 2013. Bassett was reported to have a role in the film in June 2012, the month before filming began.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://deadline.com/2012/06/angela-bassett-added-to-olympus-has-fallen-291868/|title=Angela Bassett Joins 'Olympus Has Fallen'|date=June 25, 2012|first=Dominic|last=Patten}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.vulture.com/2012/06/angela-bassett-olympus-has-fallen-secret-service.html|title=Angela Bassett Joins Olympus Has Fallen|date=June 26, 2012|work=Vulture|first=Margaret|last=Lyons}}</ref> In an interview with ''[[The Huffington Post]]'', Bassett noted that there had "never been a female head of the Secret Service, much less a woman of color". She called the decision to have a female African-American Secret Service director "a bold casting choice". Overall, Bassett viewed the film as authentic.<ref>{{cite news|author= Brennan Williams|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/03/26/angela-bassett-talks-olympus-has-fallen-waiting-to-exhale-sequel_n_2955867.html|title=Angela Bassett Talks 'Olympus Has Fallen' And 'Waiting To Exhale' Sequel|date=March 26, 2013|work=Huffington Post}}</ref> Bassett described working with [[Morgan Freeman]] as wonderful, but she admitted to being intimidated by him. She was impressed with the preparation of director [[Antoine Fuqua]], who she said "was just preparation to the hilt" and expressed her interest in working with him again.<ref name=MoviefoneBlog>{{cite news|url=http://news.moviefone.com/2013/03/20/olympus-has-fallen-angela-bassett/|title='Olympus Has Fallen': Angela Bassett Was Intimidated by 'Teddy Bear' Morgan Freeman (Exclusive)|date=March 20, 2013|first=Kelly|last=Woo}}</ref> She appeared in the 2013 film ''[[Black Nativity]]''. She sang and it was seen as contributing to the film's "blissful unreality".<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/11/27/movies/black-nativity-with-angela-bassett-and-jennifer-hudson.html|title=Christmas in Harlem, and O Come, All Ye Songs|date=November 26, 2013|work=The New York Times}}</ref> She was asked by the film's director, [[Kasi Lemmons]], if she could sing and Bassett admitted to lying to get the role. She joked to reporter Jennifer H. Cunningham, "Yes, I can sing — you didn’t ask how well!" Singing in a film was a new experience for Bassett, who had never had to sing before and had always lip-synced.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/gossip/confidential/confsub-article-1.1533259|title=Angela Bassett pipes up with a little fib to land singing role in 'Black Nativity'|date=December 1, 2013|work=New York Daily News}}</ref>
[[File:Angela Bassett at PaleyFest 2014 - 13491748704.jpg|thumb|150px|right|upleft|Bassett at [[PaleyFest]] 2014 for ''[[American Horror Story: Coven]]''.]] In 2013, Bassett appeared on FX TV show ''[[American Horror Story: Coven]]''<ref name="tvguide1"/> as [[Marie Laveau (American Horror Story)|Marie Laveau]], a voodoo witch. Bassett praised the writers, calling them "amazing".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.vulture.com/2014/05/angela-bassett-talks-ahs-freak-show.html|title=Angela Bassett Talks American Horror Story: Freak Show|date=May 2, 2014|work=Vulture|first=Katie Van|last=Syckle}}</ref> Her agent approached [[Ryan Murphy (writer)|Ryan Murphy]] about her having a role in the series and he told the agent that she was the person he had in mind for Marie Laveau. Bassett watched the previous seasons of the series before meeting with Murphy and found the writing "wonderful" and the characters "so realized".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://collider.com/angela-bassett-american-horror-story-coven-interview/|title=Angela Bassett Talks AMERICAN HORROR STORY: COVEN, Filming in New Orleans, Whether She’s Willing To Return For Another Season, and More|first=Christina|last=Radish}}</ref> Bassett's performance earned her a nomination for the [[Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Supporting Actress in a Miniseries or a Movie]]. She returned to the show for its fourth season ''[[American Horror Story: Freak Show]]'', playing Desiree Dupree, a three-breasted woman. She received another nomination for Outstanding Supporting Actress in a Miniseries or a Movie.
It was announced in May 2014 that Bassett would make her directorial debut with ''[[Whitney (2015 film)|Whitney]]'', a TV film based on the life of [[Whitney Houston]], who Bassett had worked with previously.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/lifetime-sets-whitney-houston-movie-706632|title=Lifetime Sets Whitney Houston Movie, Angela Bassett to Direct|date=May 22, 2014|work=The Hollywood Reporter}}</ref> Bassett had previously expressed interest in directing the year before.<ref name=MoviefoneBlog /> It was announced in early June 2014 that [[Yaya DaCosta]] would play Houston in the film. Houston's daughter, [[Bobbi Kristina Brown]], insulted Bassett on Twitter for not casting her as her mother in the film, to which Bassett admitted in an interview that she had never thought about casting Brown.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.mercurynews.com/entertainment/ci_26063397/whitney-houstons-daughter-blasts-angela-bassett|title=Whitney Houston's daughter blasts Angela Bassett|date=June 30, 2014|work=San Jose Mercury News}}</ref> On June 11, 2014, [[Ruby Dee]] died from natural causes. Bassett had previously worked with her on ''Betty and Coretta'' and was reported to attend the Riverside Church memorial for Dee on September 20, 2014.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/09/04/ruby-dee-memorial_n_5767372.html|date=September 4, 2014|title=Angela Bassett, Audra McDonald And Alicia Keys To Perform At Ruby Dee Memorial|work=Huffington Post}}</ref>
In the 2015 film ''[[Survivor (film)|Survivor]]'', Bassett portrayed [[United States Ambassador to the United Kingdom]] Maureen Crane.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://deadline.com/2013/10/millennium-sets-milla-jovovich-emma-thompson-pierce-brosnan-angie-bassett-for-survivor-thriller-pic-605489/|title=Millennium Sets Milla Jovovich, Emma Thompson, Pierce Brosnan, Angela Bassett For ‘Survivor’ Thriller Pic|first=Mike|last=Fleming, Jr.|date=October 7, 2013|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]}}</ref> In a negative review of the film, Mark Kermode lamented Bassett "appears from behind closed doors like a celebrity guest on ''[[Stars in Their Eyes]]''."<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2015/jun/07/survivor-film-review-pierce-brosnan-milla-jovovich|title=Survivor review - you'll wish you hadn't made it to the end|date=June 7, 2015|first=Mark|last=Kermode|publisher=The Guardian}}</ref>
Basset also voiced the character Six in the first person shooter game, ''[[Tom Clancy's Rainbow Six Siege]]''.
In March 2016, Bassett appeared in ''[[London Has Fallen]]'', reprising her role as Lynne Jacobs.<ref name="London, Butler and others">{{cite web|url=http://collider.com/olympus-has-fallen-sequel-london-has-fallen-gerard-butler/|title=Olympus Has Fallen – Sequel – London Has Fallen – Moving Forward with Gerard Butler|date=October 29, 2013}}</ref> Bassett noted it was "the very first sequel I've ever done" and that she had been excited at the prospect of another film after the initial success of ''Olympus Has Fallen''.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://abcnewsradioonline.com/entertainment-news/angela-bassett-gets-sequel-experience-in-new-thriller-london.html|title=Angela Bassett Gets Sequel Experience In New Thriller, "London Has Fallen"|date=March 4, 2016|publisher=ABC News}}</ref> In June 2016, the [[Human Rights Campaign]] released a video in tribute to the victims of the [[2016 Orlando nightclub shooting|2016 Orlando gay nightclub shooting]]; in the video, Bassett and others told the stories of the people killed there.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hrc.org/blog/watch-49-celebrities-honor-49-victims-of-orlando-tragedy-in-new-ryan-murphy |title=49 Celebrities Honor 49 Victims of Orlando Tragedy | Human Rights Campaign |publisher=Hrc.org |date= |accessdate=June 30, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last=Rothaus |first=Steve |date=June 12, 2016 |title=Pulse Orlando shooting scene a popular LGBT club where employees, patrons 'like family' |url=http://www.miamiherald.com/news/local/community/gay-south-florida/article83301677.html |work=The Miami Herald |access-date=June 15, 2016}}</ref> Bassett appeared in ''[[American Horror Story: Roanoke]]''. She also directed its sixth episode, which aired October 19, 2016. The episode marks the third time a woman has directed the show. Co-creator Ryan Murphy praised Bassett in an interview with E! News, saying he told her she would "'do this big, big episode and you're going to knock it out of the park,' and she did. And I've seen it time and time again with these women that we brought into this directing world that they're just killing it, and they're working twice as hard because they know they have a lot to prove."<ref>{{cite web|last1=Dos Santos|first1=Kristin|title=Why Tonight's American Horror Story Is a Major First for Women|url=http://www.eonline.com/news/803004/why-tonight-s-american-horror-story-means-good-things-for-women|website=E! Online|accessdate=October 20, 2016}}</ref>
In March 2017, Bassett appeared in "Ache", an episode of the television series ''[[Underground (TV series)|Underground]]''.<ref>{{cite episode|title=Ache|first1=Misha|last1=Green|first2=Joe|last2=Pokaski|date=March 22, 2017|number=13|series=''Underground''}}</ref> Executive producer and director Anthony Hemingway said her character "was written with Angela in mind" and that the entire cast came to see Bassett the day she filmed her performance.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://variety.com/2017/tv/news/underground-angela-bassett-cameo-ernestine-mom-1202014060/|title=How ‘Underground’ Scored That Angela Bassett Cameo|first=Joe|last=Otterson|date=March 22, 2017|publisher=Variety}}</ref> In May 2017, Bassett appeared in an episode of ''[[Master of None]]'', portraying major character Denise's mother Catherine.<ref>{{cite episode|title=[[Thanksgiving (Master of None)|Thanksgiving]]|date=May 12, 2017|number=18|series=''Master of None''|first1=Aziz|last1=Ansari|first2=Lena|last2=Waithe}}</ref> Lena Waithe wanted Bassett after being impressed by her previous work though was convinced she would turn down the role and said Bassett's inclusion influenced the series drastically with "another layer" of tension.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.vanityfair.com/hollywood/2017/05/master-of-none-season-2-thanksgiving-lena-waithe|title=How Angela Bassett Pushed Master of None’s "Thanksgiving" to the Next Level|date=May 16, 2017|publisher=Vanity Fair|first=Laura|last=Bradley}}</ref> The writers of the series also favored Bassett for the role after seeing her performance in ''The Jacksons: An American Dream'' and related her character's evolution in that feature to Catherine.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://ew.com/tv/2017/05/19/master-none-angela-bassett-thanksgiving|title=Master of None: How Michael Jackson is connected to Angela Bassett's casting in 'Thanksgiving'|first=Ray|last=Rahman|date=May 19, 2017|publisher=ew.com}}</ref>
In January 2018, Bassett starred in the [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]] first responder procedural drama [[9-1-1 (TV series)|''9-1-1'']], of which she is also a producer.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://deadline.com/2018/05/9-1-1-angela-bassett-ryan-murphy-interview-1202361086/|title=‘9-1-1’s Angela Bassett Brings The Heat In First Cop Role|last=Grobar|first=Matt|date=2018-05-21|work=Deadline|access-date=2018-09-23|language=en-US}}</ref> In February 2018, Bassett starred in the acclaimed Marvel superhero film [[Black Panther (film)|''Black Panther'']], as [[Ramonda (comics)|Dowager Queen Ramonda]], mother of the [[Black Panther (comics)|titular character]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.essence.com/celebrity/angela-bassett-reveals-thing-took-black-panther-set/|title=Angela Bassett Reveals The One Thing She Took From 'Black Panther' Set|work=Essence|access-date=2018-09-23|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2018/feb/18/black-panther-has-burden-no-superhero-strong-enough-to-carry|title=Black Panther has a burden that no superhero is strong enough to carry {{!}} Kenan Malik|last=Malik|first=Kenan|date=2018-02-18|website=the Guardian|language=en|access-date=2018-09-23}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.npr.org/2018/02/18/586888497/black-panther-and-the-very-important-black-film|title='Black Panther' And The 'Very Important Black Film'|work=NPR.org|access-date=2018-09-23|language=en}}</ref>
== Roles == Bassett has been noted for portraying real life African-American women, as well as strong women. Bassett said in 2001 that she liked those roles and added: "That's the image that I like to put out there, and those are the parts I'm attracted to. But not iron-fist kind of strong, just self-assured. I'm nice too."<ref name=TheGuardian2001 /> She has turned down roles which she viewed as demeaning to her image. "This is a career about images. It's celluloid; they last for ever. I'm a black woman from America. My people were slaves in America, and even though we're free on paper and in law, I'm not going to allow you to enslave me on film, in celluloid, for all to see. And to cross the water, to countries where people will never meet people who look like me. So it becomes a bigger thing than me just becoming a movie star, and me just being on TV. So if you're going to show every black woman as 400lb or every black woman as the prostitute on the street ... But I have always maintained that [the roles] I cannot do because of the way I'm made up, or because of the way I think, I don't begrudge that there is someone else who has no issues with that."<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2009/feb/12/question-time-angela-bassett|date=February 11, 2009|title=Question time: Angela Bassett on why she is drawn to playing strong women|work=The Guardian|first=Hannah|last=Pool|authorlink=Hannah Pool}}</ref>
==Personal life== [[File:Angela Bassett and Courtney Vance 2 by David Shankbone.jpg|thumb|Bassett with her husband, [[Courtney B. Vance]], March 1, 2007]] Bassett married actor [[Courtney B. Vance]] in 1997. In the summer of 2005, they starred together in a production of ''[[His Girl Friday]]'' at the [[Guthrie Theater]] in [[Minneapolis]], Minnesota. The couple's twins – son Slater Josiah Vance and daughter Bronwyn Golden Vance – carried by a surrogate, were born on January 27, 2006.<ref>[http://www.people.com/people/gallery/0,,20005166_20001238,00.html "Angela, Courtney, Slater and Bronwyn"], ''People''.</ref>
Bassett is a supporter of programs for the arts, especially for youth. She annually attends events for children with [[diabetes]] and those in foster homes. She is an active Ambassador of [[UNICEF]] for the United States. Bassett is a supporter of the Royal Theater Boys & Girls Club in her hometown of St. Petersburg, Florida.<ref>{{Cite journal|date=February 10, 2010|title=Simmons Leadership Conference Celebrates "Spirit of Resilience" with Keynote Speakers Angela Bassett, Tina Brown, Mia Farrow, and Sheryl WuDunn|url=http://go.galegroup.com/ps/i.do?p=AONE&sw=w&u=tamp44898&v=2.1&id=GALE%7CA218576318&it=r&asid=a1ccfec0043cd00746e00ef8e92a42a0|journal=PR Newswire|language=English}}</ref>
She is represented by the Executive Speakers Bureau of [[Memphis, Tennessee|Memphis]].<ref name="executivespeakers">{{cite web| url = http://www.executivespeakers.com/speakerBioDetails.asp?speaker=Angela+Bassett&theSpeaker=1111| title = Executive Speakers Bureau, Angela Bassett| publisher = Executivespeakers.com| date = | accessdate = August 7, 2010| deadurl = yes| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110710211529/http://www.executivespeakers.com/speakerBioDetails.asp?speaker=Angela+Bassett&theSpeaker=1111| archivedate = July 10, 2011| df = }}</ref>
In early 2007, Bassett donated $2,300 to the [[Barack Obama presidential primary campaign, 2008|presidential campaign]] of [[Barack Obama]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2007/POLITICS/04/16/celebrity.contributions/index.html|title=Celebrities ante up for Democratic campaigns|publisher=CNN|first=Robert|last=Yoon|date=April 16, 2007}}</ref> Bassett supported Obama in his reelection campaign. In June 2012, she made an appearance at the St. Petersburg office of his campaign and said the election was not one "where we can sit on the sidelines".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.tampabay.com/blogs/the-buzz-florida-politics/content/angela-bassett-stumps-obama-st-pete-hometown|title=Angela Bassett stumps for Obama in St Pete hometown|date=June 29, 2012|work=Tampa Bay Times|first=Adam C.|last=Smith|access-date=September 13, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140913104446/http://www.tampabay.com/blogs/the-buzz-florida-politics/content/angela-bassett-stumps-obama-st-pete-hometown|archive-date=September 13, 2014|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}}</ref> Bassett attended the [[second inauguration of Barack Obama]] on January 20, 2013.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/01/22/angela-bassett-on-obama-presidents-historic-inauguration_n_2528925.html|title=Angela Bassett On Obama: Actress Opens Up On President's Historic Inauguration (VIDEO)|date=January 22, 2013|work=Huffington Post}}</ref> She endorsed [[Hillary Clinton]] for president during the [[United States presidential election, 2016]], saying "Bar none, Clinton would make a great president."<ref>{{cite web|title=Celebrities who support Hillary Clinton|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/pictures/celebrities-who-support-hillary-clinton-election-2016/24/|website=cbsnews.com|publisher=CBS News|accessdate=August 17, 2016}}</ref> Bassett also spoke at the [[2016 Democratic National Convention]], introducing survivors of the previous year's [[Charleston church shooting]], an incident about which she spoke during her remarks.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://ew.com/article/2016/07/27/angela-bassett-gun-control-dnc/|title=DNC: Angela Bassett speaks out against gun violence|date=July 27, 2016|first=Evan|last=Slead|publisher=Entertainment Weekly}}</ref> After Clinton was defeated in the general election, Bassett tweeted, "Only 1455 days until November 3, 2020. Rest up my country. #ProudOfHer".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.shefinds.com/celebrities-react-to-donald-trump-winning-the-presidential-election/ |title=Celebrities React To Donald Trump Winning The Presidential Election|first=Sara|last=Alderman|date=November 9, 2016|publisher=shefinds.com}}</ref>
Bassett was initiated as an honorary member of [[Delta Sigma Theta]] sorority on July 13, 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://thejasminebrand.com/2013/07/13/actress-angela-bassett-susan-l-taylor-become-members-of-delta-sigma-theta/ |title=[Photos] Actress Angela Bassett & Susan L Taylor Become Members of Delta Sigma Theta |publisher=theJasmineBRAND |date= |accessdate=November 30, 2013}}</ref>

[[File:BLW Reliquary Cross crop.jpg|thumb]] [[File:Psalter of Oswald - Harley 2904 f3v Crucifixion.jpg|thumb|[[Ramsey Psalter]], tinted drawing of the Crucifixion, f.3v]] The '''Reliquary Cross''' is a late 10th century [[Anglo-Saxon art|Anglo Saxon]] ivory figure of Christ, set on an [[Ottonian Art|Ottonian]] cross to make a [[reliquary]] in the form of a [[crucifix]]. It is now in the [[Victoria and Albert Museum]] in London (Cat. 7943-1862, usually on display in room 8, case 16, in the "Medieval and Renaissance" gallery).<ref name="auto">V&A</ref>
The cross is made of [[cedar wood]] and covered with plates of gold [[filigree]] work. The "corpus" or figure of Christ, was probably made in [[Winchester]], and is in [[walrus ivory]]; the [[Titulus (inscription)|titulus]] and medallions are in [[cloisonné|cloisonné enamel]], and apparently also English.<ref name="auto"/> The body of the reliquary, because of a technical "trick" in the gold filigree, is thought to be German, around the same date, probably from the area of [[Aachen]] and [[Essen]].<ref>Wilson, 194</ref>
The V&A says "the cross is one of the rare surviving pieces which give substance to descriptions in contemporary documentary sources of the sumptuous church furnishings of pre-Conquest England. The enamels are unique in Anglo-Saxon art and may have been made by an English goldsmith familiar with German work. The wood core of the cross was perhaps regarded as a [[relic]] of the [[True Cross]]. It is most unlikely because of its size and weight, that it was made to be worn as a [[pectoral cross]] and more probable that the suspension loop allowed it to hang above an altar or shrine."<ref name="auto"/>
== Description == The body of the cross is of cedar wood, covered with sheets of gold, the back with repousse decoration now badly crumpled and flattened, the front decorated with filigree work, enamels and an ivory corpus of the figure of Christ. This is carved in walrus ivory. Haloed and crowned, the bearded Christ wears an elaborately pleated loin-cloth, knotted through the folded girdle. The head leans towards the right shoulder and the long hair falls in several plaits onto the shoulders. The figure is held in place by golden nails through the palms. The [[Titulus (inscription)|titulus]] above Christ and four medallions with emblems of the [[Four Evangelists|Evangelist]]s are of cloisonné enamel. The back of the cross shows the [[Lamb of God|Holy Lamb]] and the emblems of the Evangelists in repoussé or beaten work.<ref name="auto"/>
The height of the cross is 18.5 cm, the width 13.7 cm, the depth 2.6 cm, the weight 0.22 kg. The height of the figure is 12.2 cm, the width 10.9 cm.<ref name="auto"/>
In 1926, during cleaning work, a human finger, perhaps female, was found in a cavity underneath the corpus. A fragmentary and not totally legible inscription around the edge of the cross seems to list the relics of saints once contained in the cavity beneath the ivory figure of Christ. : 'IHS NAZARENUS' : RE(LIQVIE LIGNI) ....VLQ DE...O ET CAMIN....(IHS.XPS) AMD NIS//RV....EDA....DI....DI SIMEONIS ET MAR<ref name="auto"/>
Despite Papal disapproval of the dismemberment of saints, a finger relic was by no means unusual in Anglo-Saxon England: King [[Athelstan]] bestowed one third of his extensive collection of relics to the [[Exeter monastery|monastery of St. Mary and St. Peter]] at [[Exeter]] in AD 932. The gift included a finger, purportedly that of [[Mary Magdalene]].
[[David M. Wilson|David Wilson]] points to the close similarity between the figure on the cross and that in a tinted drawing in the [[Ramsey Psalter]], dated 980-1000.<ref>Wilson, 194-195</ref>
<!-- Object history note From the Webb Collections, £145. Formerly in the Soltikoff Collection (Sale 1861, No.94) King Alfred Exhibition RF.2007/490 --> <!-- Details of the role played by Constantine's mother Helena in finding the cross are not mentioned in Eusebius Life of Constantine and may be apocryphal Veneration of the True Cross in Jerusalem is referred to in the Catecheses of Cyril of Jerusalem, dating the earliest reported practice to ca. 340AD.Although relics of the cross proliferated after this date they lost none of their spiritual potency and were frequently used as gifts between royalty and the upper echelons of the clergy : Radegunda, Queen of the Franks obtained a relic of the True Cross from the Emperor Justin II, in 569 and Gregory the Great (540-604) sent a portion of the Cross to Theodolinda, Queen of the Lombards and another to Recared, the first Catholic King of Spain. The Golden Legend which relates details of the Legend of the True Cross records a tradition that the cross was fashioned of four different woods: cypress, olive, the wood of the palm-tree and cedar. -->

VI. 27 <!-- Magdeburg Exhibition RF.2000/360 --> * Williamson, Paul (ed.), ''The Medieval Treasury'', London: V&A Publications, 1998, p. 96 * Mitchell, H.P, ''English or German ? - A Pre-Conquest Gold Cross'', Burlington Magazine XLVII 1925, p 324 <!-- * Okasha, E. Hand-list of Anglo-Saxon Non-Runic Inscriptions (Cambridge University Press, 1971) pp 137-138 * Janet Backhouse, DH Turner, Leslie Webster, ed. The Golden Age of Anglo-Saxon art 966-1066 , London British Museum 1984, cat. no. 118 (Webster) and pl. XXVI --> * Williamson, Paul. ''Medieval Ivory Carvings. Early Christian to Romanesque.'' London, V&A Publishing, 2010, pp. 238-241, cat.no. 60 *[[David M. Wilson|Wilson, David M.]]; ''Anglo-Saxon Art: From The Seventh Century To The Norman Conquest'', Thames and Hudson (US edn. Overlook Press), 1984. <!-- Exhibition History * King Alfred: Wealth, Wisdom and Warfare (Winchester Discovery Centre 01/02/2008-27/04/2008) * Otto the Great, Magdeburg and Europe (Magdeburg Museum of Cultural History, Magdeburg 27/08/2001-02/12/2001) --> [[Category:Reliquaries]] [[Category:Anglo-Saxon art|Reliquary]] [[Category:Ivory works of art]] [[Category:Reliquary crosses]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2015}} {{Use British English|date=August 2015}} '''Antlers Gallery''' is a [[Commercial art|commercial gallery]] based in [[Bristol]] England. Created in 2010 by gallery Director Jack Gibbon, Antlers Gallery produces temporary exhibitions across varying locations, with their only permanent base being online. Dubbed the '[[nomadic]]' gallery, they use a similar business model to pop – up galleries but tie these together under the gallery brand. Antlers also have an active publishing wing working with artists producing limited edition prints and multiples.
Antlers Gallery represent a group of contemporary artists through exhibitions, art fairs and consultancy. Although primarily based in Bristol – with exhibitions held in areas such as [[Park Street, Bristol|Park Street]], [[Cabot Circus]], [[Whiteladies Road]], [[Christmas Steps, Bristol|Christmas Steps]] and [[Bristol Temple Meads railway station]]. Previous exhibitions have also been held in [[Stroud]], [[Yorkshire]] and [[London]]. Antlers Gallery exhibit at art fairs across the U.K, including the [[Affordable Art Fair]]s and [[London Art Fair]].
The Antlers model is based on mutually beneficial relationships with private landlords. These have included:- [[Land Securities]], TCN UK, Jess Properties, Kingsley Thomas, and Linden Homes.
Their first pop-up [[Art exhibition|exhibition]] ''Grotesques'' opened in December 2010. Followed by: ''Uncanny Views'', ''Dark Suits'', ''Botany'', ''Anatomy'', ''Other Nature'', ''Still Chaos'', ''Excursus'', ''Old Beliefs'', ''Narrative'', ''Spatial'', ''BLACKLIGHT'', ''Kindred'' and ''Hiatus''.
In March 2014 Antlers Gallery took over the newly renovated warehouse space Purifier House, next to [[Bristol Harbour|Bristol's Harbourside]] and [[Millennium Square (Bristol)|Millennium Square]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Antlers gallery takes over Purifier House on Bristol Harbourside |url=http://www.bristolpost.co.uk/Antlers-takes-harbour-gas-works/story-20838315-detail/story.html |work=Bristol Post |date=21 March 2014 |accessdate=24 August 2014 }}</ref> The property, owned by Linden Homes, showcased three Antlers exhibitions: ''Gravitas'', ''Exploration'' and [[Anima mundi|''Anima Mundi'']].
[[Anima mundi|''Anima Mundi'']] ran from 5 – 27 July. The main focus of the exhibition was a 5m long, concertina bookwork created by Tim Lane. The publication of the bookwork was made possible due to the support of over 140 people who pledged support via the [[Kickstarter]] campaign which raised almost £18,000.<ref>https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/antlersgallery/anima-mundi-tim-lanes-5-metre-concertina-book-draw</ref> The exhibition received much media attention, including ''[[BBC News]]''<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-bristol-27146637 | work=BBC News | title=Bristol artist creates giant concertina book | date=25 April 2014}}</ref> and ''[[The Independent]]''.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/art/features/tim-lanes-vivid-illustrations-bring-timeless-themes-of-love-and-death-to-life-9529973.html | location=London | work=The Independent | first=Jess | last=Denham | title=Tim Lane's vivid illustrations bring timeless themes of love and death to life | date=23 June 2014}}</ref> In 2014 Antlers Gallery was recognised by ''[[The Guardian]]'' as one of the top ten venues in Bristol.<ref>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2014/mar/28/top-10-arts-culture-venues-bristol</ref>
== Artists == Artists represented by Antlers Gallery include: Abigail Reed, Alexander Korzer – Robinson, Anouk Mercier, Charles Emerson, Dorcas Casey, Ellie Coates, [[Geoff Diego Litherland]], Helen Jones, Jemma Appleby, Jessica Bartlett, Jo Lathwood, Jonny Byles, Karin Krommes, Kate Evans, Matthieu Leger, Max Naylor, Rachel Sokal, Rebecca Hiscocks, Rose Sanderson, Sarah Jeffs, and Tim Lane.
== External links == * {{Official website|http://www.antlersgallery.com/|Antlers Gallery official website}}
