In [[West Virginia]] [[folklore]], the '''Flatwoods monster''', also known as the '''Braxton County Monster''' or '''Phantom of Flatwoods''', is an entity reported to have been sighted in the town of [[Flatwoods, West Virginia|Flatwoods]] in [[Braxton County, West Virginia]], United States, on September 12, 1952, following the appearance of a bright object crossing the night sky. Nearly fifty years later, investigators concluded that the light was a meteor and the creature was a [[barn owl]] perched in a tree, with shadows making it appear to be a large humanoid.
== History == {{Location map|West Virginia|label=|marksize=6|mark=Blue_pog.svg|lat_dir=N| lat_deg=38|lat_min=43 |lat_sec=17|lon_dir=W|lon_deg=80|lon_min=39|lon_sec=11| position=right| float=right|caption=Location of Flatwoods, West Virginia}} At 7:15 p.m. on September 12, 1952, two brothers, Edward and Fred May, and their friend Tommy Hyer said they saw a bright object cross the sky and land on the property of local farmer G. Bailey Fisher. The boys went to the home of Kathleen May, where they told their story. May, accompanied by the three boys, local children Neil Nunley and Ronnie Shaver, and [[West Virginia National Guard]]sman Eugene Lemon, went to the Fisher farm in an effort to locate whatever it was that the boys said they had seen. The group reached the top of a hill, where Nunley said they saw a pulsing red light. Lemon said he aimed a flashlight in that direction and momentarily saw a tall "man-like figure with a round, red face surrounded by a pointed, hood-like shape".<ref name=nickell1 />
Descriptions varied. In an article for ''[[Fate (magazine)|Fate Magazine]]'' based on his tape-recorded interviews, UFO writer [[Gray Barker]] described the figure as approximately {{convert|10|ft|m|sigfig=2|lk=on}} tall, with a round blood-red face, a large pointed "hood-like shape" around the face, eye-like shapes which emitted greenish-orange light, and a dark black or green body.<ref name="Barker1953">{{cite magazine |last=Barker |first=Gray |editor-last=Webster |editor-first=Robert N. |title=The Monster and the Saucer |magazine=[[Fate (magazine)|Fate]] |date=January 1953 |volume=6 |issue=1 |pages=12–17}}</ref> Kathleen May described the figure as having "small, claw-like hands", clothing-like folds,<ref name=nickell1>{{cite magazine |last=Nickell |first=Joe |authorlink=Joe Nickell |title=The Flatwoods UFO Monster |date=2 November 2000 |url=http://www.csicop.org/si/show/flatwoods_ufo_monster/ |magazine=[[Skeptical Inquirer]] |publisher=[[Committee for Skeptical Inquiry|CSICOP]] |volume=24 |issue=6 |pages=15–19}}</ref> and "a head that resembled the [[ace of spades]]".<ref name="Griffin2002">{{cite journal |last=Griffin |first=Buddy |editor-last=Lilly |editor-first=John |title=The Legend of the Flatwoods Monster |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=liLXAAAAMAAJ |date=Fall 2002 |journal=Goldenseal |publisher=State of West Virginia, Department of Commerce |volume=28 |issue=3 |pages=56–61}}</ref> According to the story, when the figure made a hissing sound and "glided toward the group", Lemon screamed and dropped his flashlight, causing the group to run away.<ref name="BraxV">{{cite web|title=Flatwoods Monster|url=http://braxtonwv.org/FlatwoodsMonsterInfo.aspx|website=Braxtonwv.org|publisher=Braxton County Convention and Visitor's Bureau|accessdate=10 May 2018}}</ref>
[[File:Flatwoods monster newspaper1.jpg|thumb|upright=1.1|right|September 14, 1952 news clip from the [[Charleston Daily Mail]].]] The group said they had smelled a "pungent mist" and some later said they were nauseated. The local sheriff and a deputy had been investigating reports of a crashed aircraft in the area. They searched the site of the reported monster but "saw, heard and smelled nothing". According to Barker's account, the next day, A. Lee Stewart, Jr. of the ''Braxton Democrat'' claimed to discover "skid marks" in the field and an "odd, gummy deposit"<ref name=nickell1/><ref name="Barker1953"/> which were subsequently attributed by UFO enthusiast groups as evidence of a "saucer" landing.<ref name=sci1>{{cite journal | title = More On The "Green Monster" | journal = Civilian Saucer Investigation (Winter Edition) | volume = 1 | issue = 2 | publisher = Project 1947 (Republished by) | date = 1953 | url = http://www.project1947.com/shg/csi/csiv1-2.html | accessdate = 2006-11-01 }}</ref><ref name=nickell1/>
According to former news editor Holt Byrne, "newspaper stories were carried throughout the country, radio broadcasts were carried on large networks, and hundreds of phone calls were received from all parts of the country". The national press services rated the story "#11 for the year". A minister from [[Brooklyn]] came to question the May family. A [[Pittsburgh]] paper sent a special reporter. UFO and [[Fortean]] writers like Gray Barker and [[Ivan T. Sanderson]] arrived to investigate.<ref name="Byrne">{{cite web|last1=Byrne|first1=Holt|title=1966. The Phantom of Flatwoods|publisher=Sunday Gazette-Mail State Magazine, 1966.|accessdate=14 May 2018}}</ref>
== Conventional explanations == [[File:Barn-owl (Racheeo).jpg|right|thumb|upright|A barn owl, seen with "''claw-like hands''" and a face shaped "''like the [[ace of spades|Ace of Spades]]''"]] After investigating the case in 2000, [[Joe Nickell]] of the [[Committee for Skeptical Inquiry]] (CSI) concluded that the bright light in the sky reported by the witnesses on September 12 was most likely a [[meteor]], that the pulsating red light was likely an aircraft navigation/hazard beacon, and that the creature described by witnesses closely resembled an [[owl]]. Nickell suggested that witnesses' perceptions were distorted by their heightened state of anxiety. Nickell's conclusions are shared by a number of other investigators, including those of the Air Force.<ref name=nickell1/><ref name=keyhoe1>{{cite book | last = Keyhoe | first = Donald E | authorlink = Donald Keyhoe | title = Flying Saucers from Outer Space | publisher = Henry Holt | date = 1953 |asin=B0007DECOA}}</ref>
The night of the September 12 sighting, a meteor had been observed across three states—Maryland, Pennsylvania and West Virginia. According to Nickell, three flashing red aircraft beacons were also visible from the area of the sightings, which could account for descriptions of a pulsating red light and red tint on the face of the supposed monster.<ref name=nickell1/><ref name=keyhoe1/>
Nickell concluded that the shape, movement, and sounds reported by witnesses were also consistent with the silhouette, flight pattern, and call of a startled [[barn owl]] perched on a tree limb, leading researchers to conclude that foliage beneath the owl may have created the illusion of the lower portions of the creature (described as being a pleated green skirt). Researchers also concluded that the witnesses' inability to agree on whether the creature had arms, combined with Kathleen May's report of it having "''small, claw-like hands''" which "''extended in front of it''", also matched the description of a barn owl with its talons gripping a tree branch.<ref name=nickell1/><ref name="Barker1953"/><ref name="Byrne" />
According to skeptic Ryan Haupt, even though local boy Max Lockard admitted he'd driven around the site "hoping to see something" in his Chevy truck, "paranormal investigators concluded that the tracks, oily residue, and bits of a rubbery substance must have been left by the creature and not the truck". Haupt explains nausea reported by some of the witnesses as symptoms "consistent with hysteria and over-exertion".<ref name="Skeptoid">{{cite web|last1=Haupt|first1=Ryan|title=The Braxton County Monster|url=https://skeptoid.com/episodes/4434|website=Skeptoid Podcast|publisher=Skeptoid Media, 30 Sep 2014|accessdate=14 May 2018}}</ref>
==Local culture== [[File:Flatwoods_Visitor_Chair.jpg|thumb|right|upright|Flatwoods monster chair welcomes visitors near the town hall]] Local officials have erected a "Welcome to Flatwoods / Home of the Green Monster" sign on the route leading into the town.<ref name=nickell1 />
In celebration of the legend, the Braxton County Convention and Visitor's Bureau built a series of five tall chairs in the shape of the monster to serve as landmarks and visitor attractions. The town of Flatwoods also houses a museum dedicated to the monster legend and offers promotional merchandise.<ref name="BraxV" /> The Bureau rewards visitors who photograph all five chairs with "Free Braxie" stickers as part of their ongoing promotion.<ref name="BWV3">{{cite web|title=Free Braxxie|url=http://www.braxtonwv.org/braxxie|website=braxtonwv.org|publisher=Braxton County Convention and Visitor's Bureau|accessdate=10 May 2018}}</ref>
The monster legend is celebrated every year when the town of Flatwoods holds its annual festival called "Flatwoods Days". The three-day festival is a weekend of live music, and food and craft vendors.<ref name="BVW2">{{cite web|title=Yearly Events|url=http://www.braxtonwv.org/yearly-events.aspx#|website=braxtonwv.org|publisher=Braxton County Convention and Visitor's Bureau|accessdate=10 May 2018}}</ref>
==In popular culture== * The monster makes an appearance in the 2018 video game ''[[Fallout 76]]'', which takes place in the future post-apocalyptic West Virginia.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.herald-dispatch.com/features_entertainment/video-game-to-be-based-in-a-post-apocalyptic-mountain/article_09ab293b-41aa-5b78-bed4-d880937ece7a.html|title=Video game to be based in a post-apocalyptic Mountain State|last=Herald-Dispatch|first=DAVE LAVENDER The|work=The Herald-Dispatch|access-date=2018-06-12|language=en}}</ref> * The monster makes an appearance in ''[[Legend of Zelda: Majora's Mask]]'', with similar features, but a purple coloration instead of green.<ref>https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Legend_of_Zelda:_Majora%27s_Mask</ref>
== See also == {{commons|Flatwoods monster}} *[[List of reported UFO sightings]] *[[Mothman]] *[[Owlman]]
== References == {{Reflist|30em}}
{{UFOs}}
[[Category:Alleged UFO-related entities]] [[Category:Braxton County, West Virginia]] [[Category:1952 in West Virginia]] [[Category:UFO sightings in the United States]] [[Category:West Virginia folklore]] [[Category:Monsters]] [[Category:American folklore legendary creatures]] [[Category:September 1952 events]]

{{multiple image | direction = vertical | width = 250 | image1 = Lexus_IS_250_Breakwater_Blue_Metallic1.jpg | caption1 = Original image of a left-hand-drive [[Lexus IS 250]] | image2 = Lexus_IS_250_Breakwater_Blue_Metallic.jpg | caption2 = Flopped and cropped image with badge restored }} In [[photography]] and [[graphic arts]] a '''flopped image''' is a technical term for a static or moving image that is generated by a mirror-reversal of an original image across a vertical axis. This is opposed to a ''[[flipped image]]'', which means an image reversed across a horizontal axis. ''Flopping'' can be used to improve the subjective [[aesthetic]] appeal of the image in question.
== Use in advertising == There are two main uses in advertising, one practical, and one subjective. On a practical level, images of cars are often flopped to ensure cars look appropriate for left-hand-drive or right-hand-drive markets. This allows the results of a single production shoot to be used across markets, allowing a cost saving. On a subjective level, the direction in which a person is looking or a car appears to be travelling may be regarded as important. When placing a picture on a page of text, it is usual for depictions of people to face into the text, rather than off the page; thus, when compositing a page, a picture may be flopped so it may be placed either side of a column of text.
== Use in art == Cultural considerations come into play — a picture of a person eating with their left hand may be flopped for publication in a Muslim publication, due to the strong taboo against eating with the left hand in Muslim society. Similarly, [[Vincent van Gogh]] took the trouble to etch some of his originals in mirror-reversed form so that when printed, people in the image would appear, correctly, as right-handed.
An example of ''flopping'' is the use of [[Joseph Southall|Joseph Edward Southall's]] painting ''Fishermen and Boat'' as part of the art associated with [[Kate Bush]]'s album [[Aerial (album)|Aerial]]. The picture is flopped, and the name "AERIAL" added to the boat.
== Image flipping == [[Image:Billykid.jpg|right|thumb|160px|Billy the Kid. ''(Flopped [[tintype]] photo)'']] A common movie [[blooper]] is a flopped image, usually and erroneously called "[[flipped image]]s". Flopped images are common because they can be used to correct continuity errors between shots and are hard to see without extensive examination, whereas flipped images are very obvious. Examples of these can be found on several movie blooper sites.
One of the most famous flopped images is this picture of [[Billy the Kid]] carrying a [[Winchester Rifle|Model 1873 Winchester]] rifle and a pistol belt with the pistol on his left. This led people to believe he was left-handed, but it was later revealed to be a flopped image due to the cartridge loading gate on the rifle being on the wrong side.<ref>The loading gate on a Model 1873 Winchester lever action rifle is on the right side of the receiver.</ref>
== Notes == {{Reflist}}
== References == *Sorenson, Ray. {{cite web|url= http://artsci.wustl.edu/~rsorense/PAPERS/The%20Aesthetics%20of%20Mirror.pdf |title=The Aesthetics of Mirror Reversal ''Philosophical Studies'' 100/2 (2000):175-191 }} {{small|(31.7 [[Kibibyte|KiB]])}} *De Clercq, Rafael. {{cite web|url= http://perswww.kuleuven.be/~u0019039/Mirrorreversal.pdf |title=A Note on the Aesthetics of Mirror Reversal ''Philosophical Studies'' 132/3 (2007):553-563 }} {{small|(45.2 [[Kibibyte|KiB]])}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox comics creator | image = | imagesize = | caption = | birth_date = {{circa}} {{birth year and age|1952}} | birth_name = | birth_place = | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = American | cartoonist = | write = y | pencil = y | ink = y | letter = | color = | alias = | signature = <!-- very optional --> | notable works = ''[[American Splendor]]'' | collaborators = [[Harvey Pekar]], [[Gary Dumm]] | awards = | website = | subcat = American }} '''Greg Budgett''' (b. c. 1952)<ref name=WhosWho>[http://www.bailsprojects.com/bio.aspx?Name=BUDGETT%2c+GREGORY Budgett entry], ''Who's Who of American Comic Books, 1928–1999.'' Accessed Feb. 17, 2017.</ref> is a [[Cleveland]], [[Ohio]]-based<ref name=Sangiacomo /> [[comic book]] artist known particularly for his work illustrating the comics of [[Harvey Pekar]].<ref>Grimes, William. [https://www.nytimes.com/2010/07/13/arts/design/13pekar.html?_r=0 "Harvey Pekar, ‘American Splendor’ Creator, Dies at 70,"] ''New York Times'' (July 12, 2010).</ref><ref name=Sangiacomo>Sangiacomo, Michael. [http://www.cleveland.com/metro/index.ssf/2012/10/cleveland_heights_cleveland_li.html "Cleveland Heights, Cleveland libraries honoring 'American Splendor' creator Harvey Pekar,"] ''The Plain Dealer'' (October 10, 2012).</ref> Most of Budgett's work on Pekar's ''[[American Splendor]]'' and other comics has been in partnership with [[Gary Dumm]], who has [[Inker|inked]] most of Budgett's stories.
Budgett attended [[Ohio State University]], graduating with a [[Bachelor of Fine Arts]].<ref name=WhosWho /> Pekar and Budgett began working together in 1974;<ref name=Zabel>Zabel Joe. "Stepping Out: ST's Joe Zabel Interviews Harvey Pekar," ''Harvey Pekar: Conversations'', edited by Michael G. Rhode (Univ. Press of Mississippi, 2008).</ref> before ''American Splendor'', Budgett illustrated a couple of short Pekar stories (one of them in partnership with Dumm) in the [[underground comix]] anthologies ''[[Bizarre Sex]]'' and ''Flaming Baloney X''.
From [[1976 in comics|1976]] until 1988, Budgett illustrated stories in Pekar's autobiographical comics series, ''[[American Splendor]]''. Budgett was one of Pekar's most frequent early collaborators; most of his stories were inked by Dumm. Budgett drew a number of ''American Splendor'' covers as well, including issues #2, 3, 7, 8, 11, and 13.
During the 1980s, Budgett and Dumm worked on stories in ''[[Fredric Wertham|Dr. Wirtham]]'s Comix & Stories'', an [[Underground comix|underground]]/[[alternative comics]] series published by [[Clifford Neal]], as well as a number of other alternative and independent comic book series. In the early 1990s, Budgett and Dumm co-wrote and drew stories for [[Eternity Comics]]' ''Plan 9 From Outer Space: Thirty Years Later'' and their own [[Adult comics|erotic]] series ''Shooty Beagle'' and ''Woofers & Hooters'' (both with [[Eros Comix]]).
By the early 1990s, Budgett had "de-emphasized cartooning"<ref name=Zabel /> and didn't work in the industry again until 2004, when (at the urging of Gary Dumm) he illustrated another Pekar story in the 2004 collection ''American Splendor: Our Movie Year''. He was a regular contributor to [[Vertigo (DC Comics)|Vertigo]]'s two ''American Splendor'' [[Limited series (comics)|limited series]] in 2006–2008.

Vacation: 1972" ** "The Rank" ** (inks) "Love Story" (pencils by [[Gary Dumm]]) ** "A Mexican Tale" (inks by Munan) (originally published in ''Flaming Baloney X'') ** "You fuckers can leave if you wanna..." * ''American Splendor'' #2 (Harvey Pekar, 1977): ** Front and back covers ** "Guerilla Theatre: July ’74 — on the Corne" ** "On the Corner… A Sequel, June, 1976" ** "Vignettes #1 & #2" * ''American Splendor'' #3 (Harvey Pekar, 1978): ** Front cover ** "Awaking to the Terror of the New Day" ** "Awaking to the Terror of the Same Old Day" ** "Short Weekend: A Story About the Cosmic and the Ordinary" ** "Traditional Male Chauvinism" ** "Vignettes 3 thru 6" * ''American Splendor'' #5 (Harvey Pekar, 1980): ** "Coventry Night, Summer, 1976" ** "Scenes from Star Books" ** (inks) "Emil" (pencils by Gary Dumm) ** (inks) "Mrs. Roosevelt and the Young Queen of Greece" (pencils by Gary Dumm) * ''American Splendor'' #6 (Harvey Pekar, 1981): ** "Cyclical Theory [back cover]" ** "Read This" ** "Ripoff Chick" * ''American Splendor'' #7 (Harvey Pekar, 1982): ** Front cover ** "The Day Before the Be-In" * ''American Splendor'' #8 (Harvey Pekar, 1983): ** Front cover ** "In the Parking Lot" * ''American Splendor'' #11 (Harvey Pekar, 1986): ** Back cover ** "Old Guys" * "Ethnic Bakery — Sunday Morning [back cover]," ''American Splendor'' #12 (Harvey Pekar, 1987) * Back cover, ''American Splendor'' #13 (Harvey Pekar, 1988) * (insert art) "Passport to Pimlico," (story mostly penciled by [[Joe Zabel]]) ''American Splendor'' #14 (Harvey Pekar, 1989) * "Fish Story," ''American Splendor: Our Movie Year'' (Ballantine Books, 2004) * "Northwest Airlines Goes Socialist," ''American Splendor'' vol. 1, #1 ([[Vertigo (DC Comics)|Vertigo]], 2006) * "Regionalism," ''American Splendor'' vol. 1, #3 (Vertigo, 2007) * "Grocery Shopping," ''American Splendor'' vol. 1, #4 (Vertigo, 2007) * (inks) "Town Meeting," (pencils by Gary Dumm) ''American Splendor'' vol. 2, #2 (Vertigo, 2008) * (breakdowns) "Chapter Three: The Car," (finishes by Gary Dumm), ''American Splendor'' vol. 2, #4 (Vertigo, 2008)
=== Stories elsewhere === * "The Kinsman Cowboys: How'd Ya Get Inta This Bizness Ennyway?," story by [[Harvey Pekar]], inks by [[Gary Dumm]], in ''[[Bizarre Sex]]'' #4 ([[Kitchen Sink Press]], Oct. 1975) * "A Mexican Tale," story by Harvey Pekar, inks by Munan, ''Flaming Baloney X'' (Propaganda, Inc., c. 1975) * "The Puzzle," co-written, penciled and inked with [[Gary Dumm]], ''Dr. Wirtham's Comix & Stories'' #5/6 ([[Clifford Neal]], Winter 1980) * "Cheese for Cakes Sake" (back cover), co-written, penciled and inked with Gary Dumm, ''Dr. Wirtham's Comix & Stories'' #7/8 (Clifford Neal, 1982) * "Shooty Beagle Goes to the Mall," co-written, penciled and inked with Gary Dumm, ''Dr. Wirtham's Comix & Stories'' #7/8 (Clifford Neal, 1982) * "The Compleat Videots" (starring Shooty Beagle), co-written, penciled and inked with Gary Dumm, ''Dr. Wirtham's Comix & Stories'' #9/10 (Clifford Neal, Winter 1987) * "The Twilight Avenger Gallery," ''Twilight Avenger'' #3 ([[Eternity Comics]], 1988) * ''[[Plan 9 From Outer Space]]: Thirty Years Later'' #1–3 (Eternity Comics, Jan.–Mar. 1991) * ''Shooty Beagle'' #1-3, with [[Joe Zabel]] and Gary Dumm ([[Eros Comix]], Apr.–June 1991) * ''Woofers & Hooters'' (with Gary Dumm) (Eros Comix, Feb. 1992)

page.title: How to Make Good Decisions and Be Right All the Time

revision.text:
{{Infobox book | author = [[Iain King]] | name = How to Make Good Decisions and Be Right All the Time | image = File:How to Make Good Decisions and Be Right All the Time.jpg | caption = Cover of the first edition | country = United Kingdom | language = English | subject = [[Ethics]] | published = 2008 ([[Bloomsbury]]) | media_type = Print ([[Hardcover]]) | pages = 256 | isbn = 9781847063472 }} '''''How to Make Good Decisions and Be Right All the Time''''' is a 2008 book by [[Iain King]]. It sets out a history of [[moral philosophy]] and presents new ideas in ethics, which have been described as quasi-utilitarianism.<ref name="Bloomsbury Book How To Make Decisions">{{cite web|title=How to Make Good Decisions and Be Right All the Time|url= http://www.bloomsbury.com/uk/how-to-make-good-decisions-and-be-right-all-the-time-9781847063472/|publisher=Bloomsbury|date=2008-10-16}}</ref><ref name="Vocabulary Study Religion">{{cite journal|date= 2015|title=Commitment|url=http://referenceworks.brillonline.com/entries/vocabulary-for-the-study-of-religion/commitment-COM_00000237#d19890003e190|journal=Vocabulary for the Study of Religion|editors= Robert A. Segal, Kocku von Stuckrad|publisher=Brill Reference|access-date=2015-11-06}}</ref><ref name=pw>{{cite news|title=How to Make Good Decisions and Be Right All the Time (Review)|journal=Publishers' Weekly|url= http://www.publishersweekly.com/978-1-84706-347-2|date=2008|accessdate=2015-11-06}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Philosophy Documentation Center: Philosophy Now Issue 100|url=http://www.pdcnet.org/pdc/bvdb.nsf/purchase?openform&fp=philnow&id=philnow_2014_0100_0020_0022|date=Jan 2014|accessdate=2015-11-01}}</ref><ref name=Skriptura>{{cite journal| author = Bosman, Hendrik |url=http://hdl.handle.net/10520/EJC164824 |title = From Divine Command and Prophetic Goals to Sapiential Character Formation: A Survey of Old Testament Ethical Reflection Informed by Philosophical Ethics|journal = Skriptura|volume = 113|issue = 5112|pages = 1–12|date = 2014| ISSN = 0254-1807|accessdate=2015-11-06}}</ref><ref name=Quirk>{{cite book|first=Barry|last=Quirk|title=Re-imagining Government: Public Leadership in Challenging Times|publisher= Palgrave MacMillan|date=2011|isbn=978-0-230-31442-9|page=222}}</ref><ref name=Crocker>{{cite book|first=Geoff|last=Crocker|title=''An Enlightened Philosophy: Can an Atheist Believe Anything?''|publisher= [[Iff Books]]|date=2011|ISBN=978-1-84694-424-6|pages=85–86}}</ref><ref name=Watkins>{{cite book|first=David|last=Watkins B|title=Where's My Dog? The Search for Honest Leadership|publisher= WM Consulting| date=2013|isbn=978-3-033-03950-6|pages=53–54}}</ref><ref name=Schokking>{{cite thesis|type=Masters|last=Schokking|first=David J.|url=http://hdl.handle.net/11375/14398 |date=2013|title=Honest, Authentic & Distinct: Ethical Not-For-Profit Branding|publisher=McMasters University|accessdate=2015-11-06}}</ref><ref name=Monteath>{{cite thesis|type=Ph.D.|last=Monteath|first=Andrea|url=http://ro.ecu.edu.au/theses/442/|date=2011|title=Philosophy for Teenagers|publisher=Edith Cowan University}}</ref><ref name="24 and Philosophy King">{{cite web|title=24 and Philosophy|author=Chandler Brett|url= http://andphilosophy.com/2014/07/16/24-and-philosophy|publisher=Blackwell|date=2014-07-16|access-date=2015-11-06}}</ref>
== Summary == ''How to Make Good Decisions and Be Right All the Time'' has forty chapters, which are grouped into six parts.
=== Part I. The Problem: We Need to Make Decisions, But We Don't Know How (Chapters 1–6) ===
For ethical advice to be credible, the book says it cannot be perceived as arbitrary. The book cites [[The Dice Man]] – a man who makes choices based on dice rolls – as an example of advice-following which is arbitrary and so cannot be regarded as ethical.
Chapter three argues intuitions about what we should do can be more useful, but are undermined because our multiple intuitions often lead to contradictory advice (e.g. ‘help a stranger’ or ‘put family first’?). Philosophers have sought to eliminate these contradictions by locating right and wrong in a single part of the decision-making process: for example, in the actions we take (e.g. [[Kant]]), in our character (e.g. [[Aristotle]], [[virtue ethics]]) or in the consequences of our actions (e.g. [[Utilitarianism]]).
Chapter four explains how ‘do whatever is best’ (utilitarianism) still dominates modern philosophical and economic thinking.
Chapter five cites seven faults with utilitarianism. These are that it can be self-defeating; that it considers only future events and ignores the past; that it places decision-making authority in questionable hands; that it doesn’t discriminate fairly between people; that it sacrifices individual concerns to the group interest; that it down-grades promises, fairness and truth-telling; and that it doesn’t offer any clear rules.<ref name="iainbking.files.wordpress.com">[https://iainbking.files.wordpress.com/2016/04/how-to-make-good-decisions-62-point-summary.pdf ''How to Make Good Decisions...'' a 62 point summary (pdf)]</ref> The chapter also argues that the main argument for utilitarianism is invalid, and ‘empty’.<ref>http://leehopkins.com/counselling/2015/11/12/ethics-condundrum-1/</ref>
=== Part II. The Proof: Finding the Basics of Right and Wrong (Chapters 7–14) ===
Part II starts with a secular revision of [[Pascal’s Wager]],<ref name="24 and Philosophy King"/> arguing “What does it hurt to pursue value and virtue? If there is value, then we have everything to gain, but if there is none, then we haven’t lost anything.” Thus, it rationally makes sense for us to pursue something of value.<ref name="24 and Philosophy King"/>
It says that “people ultimately derive their choices from what they want to do and what other people want to do” <ref>[http://petergreenwell.com/essays/did-angela-do-good-or-bad/ ''Did Angela do Good or Bad?'' Peter Greenwell, 2015]</ref>
It then presents four different arguments for deriving a basic principle from which right and wrong can be developed. These are an adaptation of utilitarianism; an adaptation of [[John Rawls|John Rawls']] theory;<ref name="iainbking.files.wordpress.com"/> an argument from evolutionary theory;<ref>[https://philosophynow.org/issues/100/Moral_Laws_of_the_Jungle ''Moral Laws of the Jungle'', Philosophy Now magazine, 2014]</ref> and a '[[Sherlock Holmes]]' approach.
All four arguments converge on [[empathy]], [[duty|obligation]] and the ‘Help Principle’, which the book argues are kernels of a viable ethical system.<ref name="24 and Philosophy King"/> According to [[Audrey Tang]], King's philosophy advocates: "If spending one unit of your effort could help another person by two units, he detailed in his book, you should help."<ref>[https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/open-source-enlightenment-2015-part-1-audrey-tang ''Open Source Enlightenment'', Audrey Tang, 2015]</ref>
=== Part III. The Principle: Refining the Help Principle (Chapters 15–22) ===
Part III defines the Help Principle more carefully, with a section on [[autonomy]],<ref>[http://www.ijbioethics.ir/fa/ManuscriptDetail?mid=5331 International Journal of Bio-Ethics, 2014]</ref> and a critique of the [[Golden Rule#Cannot be a sole guide to action|golden rule]].
It results in an approach to ethics which combines deontology, consequentialism and virtue ethics. This has been described as quasi-utilitarianism.<ref>D’Souza, J. F. and Adams, C. K. (2016). "On Measuring the Moral Value of Action". ''Frontiers of Philosophy in China''. 11(1), pp. 122–136.</ref>
=== Part IV. The Program: Extending the Principles to Other Problems (Chapters 23–31) ===
Part IV attempts to distinguish white lies from bad lies.<ref name="Watkins"/><ref name="Schokking"/><ref>http://www.christopherxjjensen.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/05/gendels-ross-research-paper.pdf</ref> Contradicting [[Aristotle]], who believed no general rule on lying was possible, 'For he who advocates lying can never be believed or trusted,' and [[St Augustine]], who believed all lies were sinful, the book presents a definition of good lies, and argues why it is credible and superior.<ref>[http://www.sundayobserver.lk/2012/02/05/imp06.asp Sunday Observer (Sri Lanka), February 5th, 2012]</ref><ref>[http://www.ethiomedia.com/15store/4259 ''The Conundrum of Illicit Financial Flows'', Teshome Abebe, November 14, 2014]</ref>
Chapters 28 and 29 reconcile individual human rights with group interests. Both individual justice and social justice feature.
=== Part V. Practical Advice: For Real People in the Modern World (Chapters 32–38) ===
Part V deals with situations when information is not certain, and other real world problems which are absent from much academic philosophy. These problems make [[effective altruism]] impractical and rare.<ref>[https://ispitphilo.wordpress.com/ ''Food for the Mind'', by Blake Hall, May 1, 2010]</ref>
Chapter 34 argues that the notion of [[integrity]] can only make sense in ethics if it is applied to the consequences people allow to happen rather than to people themselves.
=== Part VI. The Prognosis: How to Make Good Decisions and Be Right All the Time (Chapters 39–40) ===
Part VI claims a hybrid system can be internally-consistent and address several problems of the main schools of ethics.<ref name="24 and Philosophy King"/>
Chapter 40 concludes it is impossible to make good decisions all the time because we can never know enough about the world, and the consequences of our actions. Hence, ethics can never emulate the scientific revolution by offering a simple set of rules for every situation, similar to those derived by Newton. This is because Newton’s own rules can never be applied perfectly, because we can never know how the world really is.
== About the book == It was published on December 1, 2008.<ref name="pw"/> It became a bestseller within the category of philosophy books in 2013.<ref>[http://issuu.com/bloomsburyacademic/docs/philosophy2013 Philosophy Books, 2013]</ref>
The book answers the [[Expressivism#Objections to expressivism|Frege–Geach Problem]], the [[is ought problem|Fact–Value Gap]], and the [[Open Question Argument]],<ref>[http://talks.cam.ac.uk/talk/index/63048 'Moral Philosophy for Elves' (University of Cambridge, United Kingdom)]</ref> although the given answers have been challenged.<ref name=Crocker /><ref name="iainbking.files.wordpress.com"/>
The book has been used to reconcile [[utilitarian]] and [[deontology|rules-based]] ethics.<ref>{{cite article |first=Jeevan |last=D'Souza |title=On Measuring the Moral Value of Action |publisher= Philos, China |url=https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Jeevan_Dsouza2/publication/301688068_On_Measuring_the_Moral_Value_of_Action/links/59d8ee11a6fdcc2aad0d86cf/On-Measuring-the-Moral-Value-of-Action.pdf}}</ref>
[[humanism|Humanist]] psychologists have used the book to explain why only proven phenomena is needed to prove why morality exists, and what the parameters of morality should be.<ref>{{cite article |first=Albert A. |last=Johnstone |title=Why Morality? |publisher= The Humanistic Psychologist, 46(2), 188-203. | date=2018-06-01 |url=https://insights.ovid.com/humanistic-psychologist/thum/2018/06/000/why-morality/6/00011905}}</ref> Theists have commented on the way the book grounds ethics without recourse to religion.<ref>{{cite article |title=Atheism and Theism, A Grounding of Ethics |publisher= Red Pill Religion |date=2017-12-27 |url=https://www.redpillreligion.com/2017/12/27/atheism-theism-grounding-ethics/}}</ref>
The book has been used in freshman philosophy classes, to teach teenagers,<ref name=Monteath /> and in [[SAT]]s.<ref>[https://collegereadiness.collegeboard.org/pdf/sat-practice-test-2.pdf College Board, College Readiness, SATs 2015]</ref>
== References == {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [https://iainbking.files.wordpress.com/2016/04/how-to-make-good-decisions-62-point-summary.pdf ''How to Make Good Decisions...'': A 62-point Summary]

{{italic title}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2012}} [[File:Illustrationes Florae Novae Hollandiae frontispiece.jpg|thumb|Frontispiece]]
'''''Illustrationes florae Novae Hollandiae''''' is an 1813 publication by the [[botanical illustrator]] [[Ferdinand Bauer]].
Bauer was scientific illustrator on board {{HMS|Investigator|1801|6}} during [[Matthew Flinders]]' exploration of Australia, and as such he worked closely with the expedition's naturalist, [[Robert Brown (botanist, born 1773)|Robert Brown]]. When these men returned to England in 1805, they brought with them thousands of specimens and hundreds of sketches. Initially, they planned to publish a large-scale work, to be entitled ''Illustrationes florae Novae Hollandiae'', but this venture failed, and Brown decided to publish his scientific descriptions separately, in ''[[Transactions of the Linnean Society of London]]'', and later his own ''[[Prodromus Florae Novae Hollandiae et Insulae Van Diemen]]''. Bauer then undertook to publish a lesser work himself, with Brown providing text limited to a brief preface and some captioning.<ref name="Hewson 1999">{{cite book | first = Helen | last = Hewson | year = 1999 | title = Australia: 300 years of botanical illustration | publisher=CSIRO Publishing | location = Collingwood, Victoria | isbn = 0-643-06366-8}}</ref>
Unusually, Bauer not only did all the illustrations, but also engraved the printing plates and hand-coloured the illustrations. It was exceedingly unusual for a single artist to perform all three roles; it is said that Bauer did the engraving himself because he could not find a good engraver, and previous works of his were disappointing because of incompetent engraving.<ref name="Hewson 1999"/>
Three issues of ''Illustrationes florae Novae Hollandiae'' were published, all in 1813. These three issues totalled fifteen plates, and a sixteenth was bound into some copies. Publication then ceased, probably because the venture was a financial failure.<ref name="Hewson 1999"/> It is estimated that less than fifty copies of the work were sold, and some of these were uncoloured. It is therefore now an extremely rare book. In 1997, a copy was sold at [[Christie's]] for $57,000.<ref name="biodiversitylibrary">{{cite web | title = Bauer, Ferdinand | url = https://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/creator/450 | accessdate = 14 September 2007}}</ref>
<gallery> Banksia coccinea (Illustrationes Florae Novae Hollandiae plate 3).jpg|Plate III: ''[[Banksia coccinea]]'' </gallery>

{{For|the Indigenous cricket tournament|Imparja Cup}} {{EngvarB|date=June 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2014}} {{Use Australian English|date=July 2018}} {{Infobox television channel | name = Imparja Television | logofile = Imparja Television logo, 2008.png | logosize = 200px | logocaption = | launch = 2 January 1988 | closed date = | picture format = [[576i]] ([[Standard-definition television|SDTV]]) [[Anamorphic widescreen|16:9]] | network = | owner = [[Imparja Television Pty Ltd]] | slogan = ''Imparja'' | country = [[Australia]] | language = English | broadcast area = Remote Central and Eastern | affiliates = [[Nine Network]] | headquarters = [[Alice Springs]], [[Northern Territory]] | former names = | replaced names = | replaced by names = | sister names = | website = [http://www.imparja.com/ imparja.com] | terr serv 1 = Freeview Imparja owned ([[virtual channel|virtual]]) | terr chan 1 = 9 | sat serv 1 = [[Optus fleet of satellites#Optus C1|Optus C1]] | sat chan 1 = Transponder 6 | sat serv 2 = [[Optus fleet of satellites#Optus D1|Optus D1]] | sat chan 2 = Transponder 15 | sat serv 3 = HiTRON (Papua New Guinea) ([[virtual channel|virtual]]) | sat chan 3 = 5 }}
'''Imparja Television''' (IMP) is an Australian television station servicing remote eastern and central Australia, that began broadcasting on 2 January 1988. It is based in [[Alice Springs]], where it has a studio and satellite uplink facility. Notably, it is controlled by [[Australian Aboriginals]] through ownership by [[Imparja Television Pty Ltd]], and is widely regarded as a symbol of Aboriginal Australia. Most viewers receive Imparja via [[free to view]] satellite transmission, whilst a smaller proportion receive it via analogue terrestrial transmission.
''Imparja'' is an [[Arrernte language|Arrernte]] word meaning [[footprints]]. The word is used to represent that Imparja Television aims to service Arrente people wherever they may live, from [[Mutitjulu]] to [[Kings Canyon (Northern Territory)|King's Canyon]] to [[Alice Springs]] to [[Tennant Creek]] and beyond. They describe their range as a footprint.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.powerhousemuseum.com/collection/database/?irn=9115 | title = Sticker produced by Imparja Television, 1999 | accessdate = 29 June 2007 | year = 2000 | publisher = Powerhouse Museum }}</ref>
In 2008, Imparja Television was identified on-air and in print as '''Nine Imparja''',<ref>{{cite press release | title = New Current Affairs Program | publisher = Imparja Television | date = 27 March 2008 }}</ref> following its dropping of Network Ten affiliation. In 2009, the station again identifies as simply "Imparja" and "IMP", although the Nine Network's nine dots seen in the logo still remain.
==History==
===Origins=== The then [[Australian Broadcasting Authority|Australian Broadcasting Tribunal]] was asked by the Federal Minister for Communications in October 1984 to inquire into the allocation of commercial television licences for a number of remote areas. Licences were granted in 1985 to the [[Golden West Network]], which broadcast to Western Australia, and [[Southern Cross Central|QSTV]] in north-eastern Australia.<ref name="company">{{cite web |url=http://www.imparja.com.au/company.htm |title=About Imparja Television |accessdate=2 September 2007 |year=2001 |work=Imparja Television |publisher=imparja.com |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070828081656/http://www.imparja.com.au/company.htm |archivedate=28 August 2007 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
In 1986 hearings for the allocation of the licence began, and the [[Central Australian Aboriginal Media Association]] (CAAMA), which began providing Central Australian radio programs in local languages in 1980, formed [[Imparja Television Pty Ltd]] as a company.<ref name="company" /> Soon after, the [[Government of the Northern Territory]] announced support to underpin the viability of the Central Zone Remote Television Service (RCTS) by offering to purchase an estimated $2 million package of services from the successful applicant. The [[Government of South Australia]] undertook a similar promise, offering loans of $1 million to Imparja if they were successful.<ref name="company" /> An extraordinary saga of political, legal and commercial intrigue then ensued during the protracted [[Australian Broadcasting Tribunal]] (ABT) hearing process, pitching Federal, State and Territory Governments against one another with loan promises being substantially watered down or withdrawn as it became apparent the CAAMA application may prevail. Windfall funding from the Australian Bicentennial Authority and the Aboriginal Development Commission ultimately underpinned the feasibility of the CAAMA bid and they were successfully allocated the licence. However subsequent Federal Administrative Tribunal court proceedings brought about by the unsuccessful applicant, Darwin based Territory Television Ltd., attempting to overturn the ABT's decision delayed construction commencement of the new service until May 1987.<ref name="Bell 2008">{{cite book|last=Bell|first=Wendy|title=A Remote Possibility: The Battle for Imparja Television|date=May 2008|publisher=IAD Press|location=Alice Springs|isbn=978-1-86465-097-6|chapter=2}}</ref>
By October 1987 the new station had begun to build rebroadcast sites and new studios and a main transmitter based in [[Alice Springs]] were completed.<ref name="Bell 2008"/> Imparja's first test program, ''[[Test Cricket|Australia versus Sri Lanka Test Cricket]]'', was telecast on 2 January 1988 in [[Alice Springs]].<ref name="company" /> Two weeks later, on 15 January 1988, the station was officially inaugurated at Imparja Television's head office in Alice Springs by Minister for Communications [[Ralph Willis]] and [[Warren Snowdon]], the Australian federal [[member of parliament#Australia|member of parliament]] for the [[Division of Lingiari]] in [[Northern Territory]].<ref name="about">{{cite web |url=http://www.imparja.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=36&Itemid=49 |title=Imparja's History |accessdate=29 June 2007 |date=29 June 2007 |work=Imparja Television |publisher=imparja.com |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070707212313/http://www.imparja.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=36&Itemid=49 |archivedate=7 July 2007 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
Imparja became the first Aboriginal member of the [[FreeTV Australia|Federation of Australian Commercial Television Stations]] and the now-defunct Regional Television Association, both dominant organisations at the time.<ref name="company" />
Imparja was chaired by [[Freda Glynn]] for its first 10 years and, for a time, she was the only female chair of a television network in the world. Freda was one of the first three founders of [[CAAMA]] – the others being [[John Macumba]] and [[Philip Batty]].
Imparja had an initial population reach of 62,000 people, which by 1993 had grown to 125,000.<ref name="about" /> Imparja was available through retransmission sites at [[Ceduna]], [[Coober Pedy]], [[Leigh Creek]] and [[Woomera, South Australia|Woomera]] in South Australia, and [[Alice Springs]], [[Tennant Creek]], [[Katherine]] and [[Bathurst Island (Northern Territory)|Bathurst Island]] in the [[Northern Territory]], as well as on the [[Optus Aurora]] [[satellite television|satellite]] platform.
Imparja initially carried programming from all three major Australian commercial television networks, but following aggregation of market area with [[Southern Cross Central|QSTV]], it affiliated with the [[Nine Network]] and [[Network Ten]]. Imparja also screened some [[ABC Television (Australia)|ABC Television]] and [[SBS Television]] indigenous programs, all in addition to original programs commissioned by the station.
===1990s=== In 1990, ''Imparja Local News'' was launched as a fifteen-minute insert of local news into the national bulletin. The station also covered the [[Northern Territory general election, 1990|Northern Territory general election]] live from its Alice Springs studios. This followed the lead taken in 1989 when the station began to produce weather reports for parts of the [[Northern Territory]], South Australia and [[New South Wales]], presented by [[Lavinia Hampton]].<ref name="company" />
By 1993, Imparja's viewing audience had doubled to approximately 125,000 Australians. This in turn led to the increased allocation of government funding in 1994 to produce ''Yamba's Playtime'', which was the station's first in-house televisual production. [[Yamba's Playtime]] features the station's official mascot, "Yamba". Also in 1994, the Imparja board of directors established the Imparja Business Development Sub Committee, to monitor and provide strategic recommendations for areas of growth for the company.
In 1995, Imparja received the [[Telstra]] Indigenous Business Award for Business of the Year.<ref name="about" /> Also in 1995, Imparja's satellite transmission moved from the [[Optus fleet of satellites#A-Class|Aussat A-Class satellites]] to the [[Optus fleet of satellites#Optus B1|Optus B1]] satellite, and the station's licence was renewed.
Two new in-house productions were launched in 1996. The first being the ''BRACS Program'', which was almost fully produced by [[Indigenous Australians|Aboriginal]] communities, and ''Corroboree Rock'', an Aboriginal music program.
Imparja's parent company, [[Imparja Pty Ltd]], converted to a [[proprietary company]] in 1997, whilst in the late 1990s, Imparja moved to digital satellite technology on the [[Optus Aurora]] platform. This meant that Imparja's satellite transmission moved from the [[Optus fleet of satellites#Optus B1|Optus B1]] satellite to the [[Optus fleet of satellites#Optus C1|Optus C1]] satellite.
===2000s=== By 2001 the station's coverage area had grown to include over 430,000 people.<ref name="company" /> Around this time 'Imparja Info Channel' ('Channel 31') was launched, providing additional programming, news, and community information to remote Aboriginal communities. The Aboriginal programming on this channel later became known as [[Indigenous Community Television]] (ICTV). In 2007, the whole channel was replaced by [[National Indigenous Television]] (NITV).
Imparja faced criticism by a number of community groups in 2004, following the station's decision to introduce advertising for alcohol for the first time. The network pledged to donate 30% of the total income received from [[alcohol advertising]] towards alcohol and substance abuse programs in communities.
In 2005, ''Imparja National News'', which primarily covered the news in [[Alice Springs]] in addition to other national and international news stories, was axed. The move was taken in anticipation of the Remote Eastern & Central Australia TV1 licence area being merged with that of [[Darwin, Northern Territory|Darwin]]. Regulations imposed by the [[Australian Communications and Media Authority]] relating to minimum levels of local news coverage led to 2006 reinstatement of ''Imparja National News''. The news service began broadcasting again from the middle of February 2006, with [[Ryan Liddle]] as presenter.<ref name="alcohol">{{cite web | url = http://www.abc.net.au/alicesprings/stories/s1501976.htm | title = DASA's stance against Imparja Television | accessdate = 2 September 2007 | date = 5 January 2004 | work = [[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]] | publisher = [[ABCL Local Radio|ABC Alice Springs]] }} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref>
In the mid-2000s, it was widely expected that the [[Australian Communications and Media Authority]] would merge the "[[Darwin, Northern Territory|Darwin]]" and "Remote Eastern and Central Australia" commercial television licence areas. This would have most likely seen Imparja Television become a [[Network Ten]] affiliate in Darwin. However, this did not eventuate. Instead [[PBL Media]] and [[Southern Cross Broadcasting]], the two existing Darwin Commercial licence holders were invited to bid individually or together. Their successful joint bid used a company called [[Darwin Digital Television]].<ref>{{cite press release | title = New digital commercial television service for Darwin | publisher = [[Australian Communications and Media Authority|ACMA]] | date = 18 May 2007 }}</ref>
On 3 February 2008, Imparja Television updated its logo removing the emblem, which had been present on the logo for two decades. The logo change coincided with Imparja dropping [[Network Ten]] affiliation, becoming a sole [[Nine Network]] affiliate, in addition to axing ''Imparja National News'', and also adding Nine Network's dots to its new logo.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.centralianadvocate.com.au/article/2008/02/01/2734_news.html |title=Footy grand final telecast in doubt |accessdate=3 February 2008 |date=1 February 2008 |publisher=Centralian Advocate |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080214184412/http://www.centralianadvocate.com.au/article/2008/02/01/2734_news.html |archivedate=14 February 2008 }}</ref><ref name="affiliation" />
===2010s=== On 19 May 2010, the ACMA (Australian Communications and Media Authority) approved a licence for a new remote area digital-only TV channel, a joint venture by Imparja Pty Ltd and Southern Cross Central.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.acma.gov.au/WEB/STANDARD/pc=PC_312142 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=18 November 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101019212642/http://acma.gov.au/WEB/STANDARD/pc%3DPC_312142 |archivedate=19 October 2010 |df=dmy-all }}.</ref> It was launched on 30 June 2010 as "[[Central Digital Television|Ten Central (CDT)]]". It had two feeds, Ten Central North (QLD/NT) and Ten Central South (NSW/SA/Vic/Tas).
In December 2010, Imparja Television began broadcasting on terrestrial digital TV and the new [[Viewer Access Satellite Television|VAST]] satellite service. This expansion included the establishment of two feeds for these platforms, Imparja North (Qld/NT) and Imparja South (NSW/SA/Vic/Tas). As of 2010, their programming is exactly the same.
Imparja Pty Ltd also began to launch digital channels [[9Go!|GO!]] and [[9Gem|GEM]].
As of the moment, Imparja continues to stream the HD feed of [[9Gem]], which was rebranded as a standard definition channel in Nine Network-only on 26 November 2015 in its metropolitan and Darwin stations, along with [[9Life]] and the relaunch of [[9HD]]. There are currently no plans at this stage for Imparja to launch an HD simulcast or introduce 9Life to its viewers. It will continue with its existing lineup of three broadcast channels.
==Programming== [[File:Imparja Television building, Alice Springs, 2015.JPG|thumb|alt=Imparja Television's headquarters in Alice Springs, 2015|Imparja Television's headquarters in Alice Springs, 2015]] Imparja Television is a sole [[Nine Network]] affiliate. The station previously broadcast both Nine and Ten programming, however it stopped broadcasting [[Network Ten]] programming on 3 February 2008.<ref name="affiliation">{{cite web |url=http://www.imparja.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=29&Itemid=39 |title=Imparja Television Aims For More Local Content |accessdate=3 February 2008 |year=2008 |work=Imparja Television |publisher=imparja.com |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080119200422/http://www.imparja.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=29&Itemid=39 |archivedate=19 January 2008 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Imparja Television has also aired original programs produced by local Aboriginal community members, such as [[Bush Mechanics]] and the children's program ''[[Yamba's Playtime]]''. Imparja also airs programming relating to local [[Australian rules football]] and community sports, as well as news updates and religious ''thought for the day'' programs. Imparja Television also regularly broadcasts films created by the [[Central Australian Aboriginal Media Association]], which is a shareholder of its parent company.
Imparja's programming schedule is currently based on the Nine Network schedule for Brisbane (based on [[Australian Eastern Standard Time|Eastern Standard Time]]). Prior to February 2008, scheduling was generally based on [[Australian Central Standard Time|Central Standard Time]], reflecting its Alice Springs-based heritage. As a result, programs are now broadcast half an hour earlier than they previously would have been under the previous arrangement.
===News and current affairs=== Imparja does not currently produce its own evening regional news bulletin. In 2008, Imparja replaced ''[[Imparja National News]]'' – a 30-minute, weeknightly program combining local and national/international news – with local news updates, plus a 30-minute local news magazine program, ''Footprints'' (which later ceased production in 2009). The news updates were presented by Emma Groves from 2014 until July 2016. This brings Imparja's daily news service roughly into line with its competitor in the Remote Eastern and Central Australia licence area, [[QQQ|Southern Cross Central (QQQ)]].
The 6:00 pm ([[Australian Eastern Standard Time|AEST]]) time slot is filled by a simulcast of ''[[Nine News Queensland]]''. Imparja cites its geographic distribution, with a majority of the remote licence area's viewers now located in Queensland, as a "key factor" in selecting the Queensland bulletin.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.imparja.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=29&Itemid=39 |title=Imparja TV to Boost News and Current Affairs |accessdate=9 January 2008 |year=2007 |work=Imparja Television |publisher=imparja.com |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080119200422/http://www.imparja.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=29&Itemid=39 |archivedate=19 January 2008 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> In 2009 Imparja began airing the Darwin edition of [[Nine News#Darwin|Nine News]] live at 6:30 pm (AEST) on weekdays, immediately following the Brisbane edition, in place of ''[[A Current Affair (Australian TV series)|A Current Affair]]'' – thereby restoring a [[Northern Territory]]-based bulletin to the station.
===Sport=== Imparja airs most sports coverage from the Nine Network, including [[rugby league]], [[cricket]], golf and tennis. The station also broadcast [[motorsport]] and [[Australian rules football]] coverage until 2008.
==Availability== Imparja Television broadcasts throughout most of the Northern Territory, and also to some remote parts of [[Queensland]], [[New South Wales]], South Australia, [[Victoria, Australia|Victoria]], [[Tasmania]] and [[Norfolk Island]]. It is generally available by satellite on the [[Viewer Access Satellite Television|VAST]] or [[Optus Aurora]] platforms, though in some locations it is broadcast terrestrially. Imparja Television has the largest geographic range of any commercial television network in Australia. Imparja is also received on the [[TT-Line (Australia)|Spirit of Tasmania]] Bass Strait Ferries.
Imparja Television was previously available in [[New Zealand]] until March 2008 when the New Zealand government pressured the Australian government to remove the service from the satellite footprint that includes New Zealand.{{Citation needed|date=October 2008}}
The total population serviced by Imparja Television is over 700,000 people, boasting the largest footprint in the southern hemisphere.
Imparja is also available in Port Moresby in Papua New Guinea through the HiTRON subscription television service.<ref>[http://www.hitron.com.pg/mmds_2006.html HiTRON Limited – Papua New Guinea :: MMDS TV] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080615202949/http://www.hitron.com.pg/mmds_2006.html |date=15 June 2008 }}</ref>
==Logos== Imparja Television's first logo was developed from a painting produced by an [[Arrernte people|Arrernte]] artist and traditional owner. The logo symbolised the [[MacDonnell Ranges]], the [[Todd River]] and the [[Yeperenye caterpillar]].<ref name="aboutlogo">{{cite web |url=http://www.imparja.com.au/company.htm |title=About Imparja Television |accessdate=9 March 2008 |year=2001 |work=Imparja Television |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071211094802/http://imparja.com.au/company.htm |archivedate=11 December 2007 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> An updated version designed by Bruce Dunlop Associates debuted on 30 January 2006, adding a blue sphere behind the emblem. When Imparja re-affiliated with Nine Network, the long-time emblem was replaced by the Nine Network dots.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.theage.com.au/news/tv--radio/mission-incredible/2007/11/28/1196036963957.html | title = Mission incredible | accessdate = 29 November 2007 |date=29 November 2007 | publisher = ''The Age'' }}</ref>

{{Infobox film | name = Jeanne Eagels | image = Jeanne eagels d.jpg | image size = | border = | alt = | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = [[George Sidney]] | producer = George Sidney | writer = | screenplay = [[John Fante]]
[[Daniel Fuchs]]
[[Sonya Levien]] | story = Daniel Fuchs | starring = [[Kim Novak]]
[[Jeff Chandler (actor)|Jeff Chandler]]
[[Charles Drake (actor)|Charles Drake]]
[[Agnes Moorehead]]
[[Larry Gates]]
[[Virginia Grey]]
[[Gene Lockhart]]
[[Murray Hamilton]] | music = [[Mischa Bakaleinikoff]]
[[George Duning]]
Gil Grau
[[Howard Jackson (composer)|Howard Jackson]] | cinematography = Robert H. Planck | editing = [[Viola Lawrence]]
[[Jerome Thoms]] | studio = | distributor = [[Columbia Pictures]] | released = {{Film date|1957|08|02|United States}} | runtime = 109 minutes | country = United States | language = English | budget = | gross = $3.1 million (US rentals)"Top Grosses of 1957", ''Variety'', 8 January 1958: 30 }} '''''Jeanne Eagels''''' (also titled '''''The Jeanne Eagels Story''''') is a 1957 American [[biographical film]] loosely based on the life of stage star [[Jeanne Eagels]]. Distributed by [[Columbia Pictures]], the film was produced and directed by [[George Sidney]] from a [[screenplay]] by [[John Fante]], [[Daniel Fuchs]] and [[Sonya Levien]], based on a story by Fuchs.''[[Variety Film Reviews|Variety]]'' film review; July 24, 1957, page 6.''[[Harrison's Reports and Film Reviews|Harrison's Reports]]'' film review; July 20, 1957, page 114. The film stars [[Kim Novak]] in the title role. [[Jeff Chandler (actor)|Jeff Chandler]], [[Charles Drake (actor)|Charles Drake]], [[Agnes Moorehead]], [[Larry Gates]], [[Virginia Grey]], [[Gene Lockhart]] and [[Murray Hamilton]] co-star. Many aspects of Eagels' real life were omitted or largely fictionalized. Eagels' family later sued Columbia Pictures over the way Eagels was depicted in the film.{{cite web|url=https://movies.nytimes.com/movie/97099/Jeanne-Eagels/overview|title=Jeanne Eagels (1957)|last=Erickson|first=Hal|publisher=nytimes.com|accessdate=January 8, 2013}} ==Plot== Jeanne Eagels is a Kansas City waitress. After losing a carnival's beauty contest, she asks carny owner Sal Satori for a job. Her dancing in a skimpy costume is accused of being obscene. Sal decides to join his brother in New York and invites Jeanne to join them in an amusement park at [[Coney Island]]. Taking acting lessons instead, the ambitious Jeanne becomes the understudy in a Broadway show and a star when she gets a chance to play the part. A once successful actress named Elsie Desmond wants to make a comeback in a new play, but Jeanne betrays her and takes the play for herself, willing to do anything to get ahead. Elsie denounces her in the theater before the first performance, then commits suicide. Sal is disgusted by Jeanne's behavior as well. She accepts a proposal from a ne'er-do-well named John Donahue, but both descend into alcoholism. Jeanne misses performances and causes fellow actors to lose out on paychecks. Her situation deteriorates further when she's required to pay alimony to John after a divorce. A new play fails because Jeanne, drunk and on pills, collapses on stage. The actors' guild suspends her for 18 months. Unable to work, she returns to Sal's amusement park and is offered a job dancing. Another performer sexually assaults her in a dressing room. Jeanne, her life in ruins, continues to spiral downward and hallucinate. While trying to make it to a stage one night, she collapses on the staircase and dies. ==Cast== {| class="wikitable" width="50%" |- bgcolor="#CCCCCC" ! Actor/Actress !! Role |- | [[Kim Novak]] || [[Jeanne Eagels]] |- | [[Jeff Chandler (actor)|Jeff Chandler]] || Sal Satori |- | [[Agnes Moorehead]] || Nellie Neilson |- | [[Charles Drake (actor)|Charles Drake]] || John Donahue |- | [[Larry Gates]] || Al Brooks |-|- | [[Virginia Grey]] || Elsie Desmond |- | [[Gene Lockhart]] || Equity Board President |- | [[Joe De Santis]] || Frank Satori |- | [[Murray Hamilton]] || Chick O'Hara |} ==Production== The film was long planned as a vehicle for Kim Novak.A Town Called Hollywood: Kim Novak 'Merges' With Spirit of Jeanne Eagels Scheuer, Philip K. Los Angeles Times (1923-Current File) [Los Angeles, Calif] 06 Jan 1957: E2. Jeff Chandler had just finished a long term exclusive contract with Universal and played the male lead.Movie to Team McCrea and Mark Stevens Hopper, Hedda. Chicago Daily Tribune (1923-1963) [Chicago, Ill] 08 Dec 1956: 18. Novak's dress caught on fire during filming and Chandler had to put it out.Kim Novak Escapes As Dress Catches Fire The Washington Post and Times Herald (1954-1959) [Washington, D.C] 15 Feb 1957: A24. ==Soundtrack== * "Half Of My Heart", written George W. Duning, Ned Washington 1957, recorded by [[Jeff Chandler (actor)]] 1958, Love Theme From "Jeanne Eagels (film)" by [[Morris Stoloff]] And His Orchestra 1958, single by [[The Four Aces]] 1957 ==DVD release== [[Sony Pictures Home Entertainment]] released ''Jeanne Eagels'' on August 3, 2010, as part of its "Kim Novak Collection." The box set also includes the films ''[[Picnic (1955 film)|Picnic]]'' (1956); ''[[Bell, Book and Candle]]'' (1958); ''[[Middle of the Night]]'' (1959); and ''[[Pal Joey (film)|Pal Joey]]'' (1957).{{cite web|url=http://www.cleveland.com/movies/index.ssf/2010/08/kim_novak_collection_offers_fi.html|title='Kim Novak Collection' offers five of her best films|last=Ball|first=Chris|date=August 4, 2010|publisher=cleveland.com|accessdate=January 8, 2013}} ==See also== * [[List of American films of 1957]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==Further reading== * {{cite book|title=George Sidney:a Bio-Bibliography|last=Monder|first=Eric|year=1994|publisher=Greenwood Press|isbn=9780313284571}} == External links == * {{IMDb title|id=0050560|title=Jeanne Eagels}} * {{tcmdb title|id=15918|title=Jeanne Eagels}} * {{amg movie|97099}} * {{AFI film|id=52241|title=Jeanne Eagels}} {{George Sidney}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Jeanne Eagels (Film)}} [[Category:1957 films]] [[Category:1950s biographical films]] [[Category:1950s drama films]] [[Category:American biographical films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:Biographical films about actors]] [[Category:American black-and-white films]] [[Category:Columbia Pictures films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:Cultural depictions of people]] [[Category:Films scored by George Duning]] [[Category:Films based on actual events]] [[Category:Films directed by George Sidney]] [[Category:Films set in the 1910s]] [[Category:Films set in the 1920s]] [[Category:Screenplays by Sonya Levien]]

[[File:Tautra-Mariakloster.jpg|thumb|Tautra Mary Convent no [[Tautra]] at [[Frosta]]]] '''Jensen & Skodvin Architects''' is a [[Norway|Norwegian]] architectural firm established in 1995 by '''Jan Olav Jensen''' (born 1959) and '''Børre Skodvin''' (born 1960). Their work has been noted and they have received awards in the field.<ref>Norwegian talks: architetture di Knut Hjeltnes , Carl-Viggo Hølmebakk e Jensen & Skodvin . A Cura di Nicola Flora e Gennaro Postiglione. Quodlibet, 2010. {{ISBN|978-88-7462-352-5}}.</ref>
Both partners were educated at the [[Oslo School of Architecture and Design]] (1985/1988) and hold part-time positions there. They have previously worked at NSB Architects. Their office has been involved in the [[Norwegian Public Roads Administration]] tourist project at [[Sognefjellsvegen]] (along with others).<ref>Jensen & Skodvin: works 1995-2009: Berlin 2009. Edited by Karl Otto Ellefsen. Academic publishing / Unipax, 2009. {{ISBN|978-82-8152-031-8}}</ref>
Jensen & Skodvin "follows a design philosophy where the final shape is a result of natural, selected and specified terms. The Liasanden picnic area and the railing on Videseter are simple examples of this"
==Work== [[File:Tautra Klosterkirche.jpg|thumb|Cistercian Monastery Tautra Maria]] [[File:DogA Hausmannsgate 16-fil2.jpg|thumb|Norwegian Centre for Design and Architecture]] [[File:Sinsen stasjon 2.jpg|thumb|[[Sinsen (station)|Sinsen Metro Station]]]] *Lady Brick, new type of brick (2007) *Juvet Landscape Hotel, Gudbrandsjuvet (2007) *Gleichenberg spa and hotel, Austria (2007) *[[Tautra Abbey|Cistercian Monastery Tautra Maria]] (2006) *Årvollskogen, housing and planning (2006) *Business Quarterly northern gate, Trondheim (2006) *Norwegian Centre for Design and Architecture (2006) *Ropeid Ferry Terminal (2003) *[[Sinsen (station)|Sinsen Metro Station]] (2003) *[[Storo (station)|Storo Metro Station]] (2003) *[[Mortensrud church]] (1998) *Bus stop, parking buildings - Oslo Airport (1998) *Service, parking buildings - Oslo Airport (1998) *Roofs, parking buildings - Oslo Airport (1998) European glulam Award - commended 1999 *Noise Monitors (1998) *[[Sognefjellsvegen]] (1997): Handrails on Videseter; Mefjellet viewpoints, rest areas at Liasanden, [[Vågåmo]], Oppstryn, [[Gaupne]] and Øvste Foss *Villa Kittilsen, Leikanger, [[Ålesund]] (1997) *Truck garage, Rolfsøy (1988), finalist for the [[Mies van der Rohe award]]
==Awards== *Houen fund certificate for 2008 *"[[Erich Schelling Architekturpreis]] for 2008. *MMARMOMACC, International stone Prize 2007 *Mortensrud (in 2007 was rated as one of postwar 12 key buildings in Norway) *Jacob Prize 2007 *[[Forum AID Award]] 2007 *Norwegian steel construction prize in 2003 *[[Grosch medal]] for 2003 *European Steel Design Award 2003 *AR + D Awards - highly commended 2002 *Treprisen - 1999
==External links== * [http://www.jsa.no/ Official website] * [http://archileaks.se/redaktionellt/kyrka-i-mortensrud// Detail drawings of Mortensrud Church]

{{About|the Belgian Catholic theologian|the German Lutheran theologian|Gerhard Wolter Molanus}} [[File:123 9 molanus pt.jpg|thumb|Molanus, a portrait destroyed by German military action in 1915{{cite web|url=http://www.uniset.ca/microstates/delannoy_louvain.htm|last=Delannoy|first=P.|title=The Library of the University of Louvain|publisher=United Settlement|date=May 1915}}]] '''Joannes Molanus''' (1533–1585), often cited simply as '''Molanus''', is the [[Latinisation of names|Latinized]] name of Jan Vermeulen or Van der Meulen,R. Van Uytven, "Molanus, Johannes", ''[[Nationaal Biografisch Woordenboek]]'', vol. 2 (Brussels, 1966), 580-582. an influential [[Counter Reformation]] Catholic theologian of [[Old University of Leuven|Louvain University]], where he was Professor of Theology, and Rector from 1578. Born at [[Lille]] (a city in the [[County of Flanders]], then under [[Habsburg Netherlands|Habsburg rule]]), he was a priest and [[canon (priest)|canon]] of [[St. Peter's Church, Leuven]], where he died. He wrote numerous books, several only published posthumously. He is best known for his ''De Picturis et Imaginibus Sacris, pro vero earum usu contra abusus'' ("Treatise on Sacred Images"). This was published in 1570, four years after the [[Beeldenstorm|Iconoclastic Fury]] had swept through the [[Low Countries]], and it defended the production and use of devotional images, but enforcing the restrictions of the [[Council of Trent]], as he interpreted them, in a brutally polemical fashion, which was very influential. Five further, enlarged, editions of this appeared between 1594 and 1771,{{cite web|url=http://www.columbia.edu/cu/arthistory/faculty/Freedberg/Johannes-Molanus.pdf|first=David|last=Freedburg|title=Johannes Molanus on Provocative paintings|page=1, note 2|accessdate=2013-12-13}} and a modern French translation was published in 1996.Molanus, ''Traité des saintes images'', ed. and trans. François Boespflug, Olivier Christin and Benoît Tassel (2 vols., Paris, 1996). He was also lead editor of an edition of the works of [[Saint Augustine]] (Antwerp, [[Plantin Press]], 1566–1577), and wrote a manuscript history of Louvain that was printed in two volumes in 1861, edited by [[P. F. X. de Ram]].Jean Molanus, ''Les quatorze livres sur l'histoire de la ville de Louvain'', ed. P. F. X. de Ram (2 vols., Brussels, 1861). ==Life== Molanus was born in [[Lille]], in [[Walloon Flanders]], in 1533, the son of Hendrik Vermeulen and Anna Peters. His father was from Holland and his mother from Brabant. He matriculated at Louvain University on 27 February 1554, graduating in the Liberal Arts in 1558 and as Doctor of Theology in 1570. He became a [[canon (priest)|canon]] of St. Peter's Church, Leuven, and a professor of Theology, serving both as dean of the [[Faculty of Theology, Old University of Leuven|Faculty of Theology]] and as rector of the university. In 1579 he was appointed president of [[King's College, Leuven|King's College]].[[Alphonse Wauters]], "Molanus, Joannes", ''[[Biographie Nationale de Belgique]]'', [http://www.academieroyale.be/academie/documents/FichierPDFBiographieNationaleTome2057.pdf vol. 15] (Brussels, 1899), 48-55. Molanus died in Louvain on 18 September 1585, having made bequests in favour of the college over which he had presided. ==Molanus and art== Molanus is today mainly remembered by art historians for being one of the first authorities to turn the [[Council of Trent]]'s short and inexplicit [[Art in Roman Catholicism#Council of Trent|decrees on sacred images]] (1563) into minutely detailed instructions for artists, which were then widely enforced in Catholic countries mostly. His views on the older, originally [[Byzantine art|Byzantine]], depiction of the [[Nativity of Jesus in art]] are typical:
The Virgin is shown pale with pains, the midwives prepare a small (narcotic) drought for the childbirth. Why this? Is it because the Virgin Mary would have held back from any pain of childbirth, when in fact she brought forth her divine son without pain? And what pertains to the midwives who are mentioned in the apocryphal Book of the Infancy? Jerome says: There was no midwife! No obtrusiveness of women intervened! She, the Virgin, was both mother and midwife! I saw in not a few places the picture of the blessed Virgin lying on a bed, depicting childbirth, and she was suffering pains from this birth, but that is not true. How stupid! Those artists ought to be laughed at who paint Mary in the very act of childbirth pains, accompanied with pain, midwife, bed, little knives (to cut the umbilical cord), with hot compresses, and many other appurtenances. . . . Rather, those pictures should be promoted which show the birth of Christ in which the Blessed Virgin Mary with arms folded and on bended knee before her little son, as though he was just now brought forth into the light.[http://www.nd.edu/~jneyrey1/MaryM&M.htm Mary: Mediterranean Maid and Mother in Art and Literature], Jerome H. Neyrey, University of Notre Dame, Abstract, Biblical Theology Bulletin 20 (1990) 65–75.
He objected on similar grounds to the ''[[Death of the Virgin]]'', her [[Swoon of the Virgin|swooning at the foot of the Cross]], and her being shown supplicating Christ for mankind in ''[[Last Judgement]]'' scenes. She would, he said, in fact be sitting alongside Christ in stern judgement:
Many painters show Mary and John the Baptist kneeling beside Our lord at the Last Judgment...But we may not think that at that day the Virgin Mary will kneel for us before the Judge, baring her breast to intercede for sinners. Nor may we think that John the Baptist will fall upon his knees to beg mercy for mankind in the way the painters show. Rather, the blessed Virgin and St. John shall sit beside the supreme Judge as assessors. The mercy which is extended now will have no place then. There will only be strict justice at that day.[http://www.paintedchurch.org/ickdoom.htm Online, with example of the depiction condemned] De Historia SS. Imaginum et Picturarum, 1594, Book iv. cap. 24. translated in A. Caiger-Smith, English Medieval Wall Paintings [Bibliography Page], p. 35.
Also condemned were [[Saint Christopher]] as a giant carrying Christ (and as the protector of travellers), [[Saint George and the Dragon]], the [[Holy Kinship]], the unicorn hunt in the [[Hortus Conclusus]] and many other depictions not verifiable from reliable sources – the ''[[Golden Legend]]'' was, he said, in fact of "lead".Mâle, online Nudity, even of the infant Jesus, was to be avoided as much as possible, and drapes must cover the genitals where it could not be.Blunt 1985, pp. 114, 118. Whilst condemning older depictions without a scriptural basis, he was not hesitant in creating new ones based on his own interpretation.Blunt 1985, p. 127; Mâle [[Saint Joseph]] should not be shown as the old, semi-comical figure of the Middle Ages, but as young, vigorous and firmly in control of the [[Holy Family]]. [[Mary Magdalene]] should not be shown as an over-dressed prostitute, and generally dress should be simple. He opposed showing the [[Swooning Virgin Mary]] in scenes of ''[[Christ carrying the Cross]]'' or the Crucifixion itself.Penny 2004, p. 26. ==Publications== *''Usuardi martyrologium'' (Leuven, 1568) [https://books.google.com/books?id=Fb36fSBlfwYC Available on Google Books] *''De Picturis et Imaginibus Sacris'' (Leuven, 1570) [https://books.google.com/books?id=h8lVAAAAcAAJ Available on Google Books] **Reworked as the posthumously published ''Historia Sanctarum Imaginum'' (Leuven, 1594) [https://books.google.com/books?id=NkFYH8uo0W4C Available on Google Books] *''Indiculus Sanctorum Belgii'' (Leuven, 1573) [https://books.google.com/books?id=vvRaAAAAQAAJ Available on Google Books] *''De fide haereticis servanda libri tres'' (Cologne, 1584) [https://books.google.com/books?id=AN5WAAAAcAAJ Available on Google Books] *''Theologiae Practicae Compendium'' (Cologne, 1585) [https://books.google.com/books?id=Qn0fcfHAxSkC Available on Google Books] *''Liber de piis testamentis'' (Cologne, 1585) [https://books.google.com/books?id=Ihq-k-lYs4cC Available on Google Books] *''De Canonicis libri tres'' (Cologne, 1587) [https://books.google.com/books?id=etI4F-5we_QC Available on Google Books] *''Militia sacra ducum et principum Brabantiae'' (Antwerp, 1592) [https://books.google.com/books?id=gS5a1jqQfTcC Available on Google Books] ==Notes== {{Reflist}} ==References== *[[Anthony Blunt|Blunt, Anthony]], ''Artistic Theory in Italy, 1450-1660'', chapter VIII, especially pp. 107–128, 1940 (refs to 1985 edn),[https://books.google.com/books?q=Artistic+Theory+in+Italy&as_brr=3] [[OUP]], {{ISBN|0-19-881050-4}} *Decavele, Johan, "Molanus, Johannes", Grove Art Online, [[Oxford Art Online]], Oxford University Press. Web. 4 Apr. 2017. [http://www.oxfordartonline.com/subscriber/article/grove/art/T058889 subscription required]. *[[Émile Mâle|Mâle, Émile]], ''L'Art religieux après le Concile de Trente, étude sur l'iconographie de la fin du XVIe, du XVIIe et du XVIIIe siècles en Italie, en France, en Espagne et en Flandre'' (1932) *[[Nicholas Penny|Penny, Nicholas]], National Gallery Catalogues (new series): ''The Sixteenth Century Italian Paintings, Volume I'', 2004, National Gallery Publications Ltd, {{ISBN|1-85709-908-7}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Molanus, Joannes}} [[Category:1533 births]] [[Category:1585 deaths]] [[Category:People from Lille]] [[Category:Flemish theologians]] [[Category:Art critics]] [[Category:University of Leuven faculty]] [[Category:Belgian Roman Catholic theologians]]
